This generation of Syrian children are going to build the peaceful future of the country. They just need the bombing to stop first: https://www.whitehelmets.org/?source=fb0509

Ahmad Alhamodn was a Syrian journalist, a photographer, a husband, a father. Yesterday he died in hospital after he had been hit by a barrel bomb attack 16 days ago. 

Last week, Ahmad's wife who was 8 months pregnant died from her injuries from the same attack. Before she entered a coma she was able to deliver a healthy daughter, who is now going to grow up without either of her parents.

Ahmad was one of the founders of the Aleppo Media Centre, a group dedicated to showing the world the plight of Syrian civilians living under Assad and Russian bombs.

Ahmad spent his life telling stories of tragedy and hope from Aleppo, now the world has lost another person working for peace in Syria.

Today we remember this hero and his family. 

RIP Ahmad

One year ago today the image of Aylan Kurdi's body washed up on a beach shocked the world 

One year ago, Aylan's family fled Aleppo, looking for safety. 

One year on, 300,000 people in Aleppo are still living in siege like conditions and under constant bombs. 

One year on, people are still fleeing from Syria. We need to ask our leaders to stop the bombs: https://act.thesyriacampaign.org/sign/we-want-to-go-home?source=fb0209

"This is not like any other job. We don't work from 9-5. As long as there are bombs falling and people to be rescued, we don't take vacation.

There are times when we work for 24 hours straight, pulling families from under the rubble and searching for survivors. We sleep when we can and take breaks when we know that another volunteer can take our place."

Majd, a White Helmet.

The White Helmets never stop. We should never stop supporting them: https://nobelpeaceprize.whitehelmets.org/en?source=fb006

status_message:
These are not fireworks, Ammar Bareesh, a student from Idlib, tells you the story of his selfie.

"I took this "selfie" when the Russians were intensively bombarding my city with napalm bombs two days ago. 

We have seen many incendiary attacks on our cities in Syria. 

The first time the Syrian regime used cluster bombs in Idlib was three years ago.  

The Russian air force also uses cluster bombs but they are a lot stronger than what the regime has been using.

These cluster bombs don't explode in the air only.  They explode when touched by a person. It's as if they are activated by the heat of a human body.

And things got even worse when the Russians started use napalm bombs in Aleppo 6 months ago and in Idlib two months ago. Napalm causes severe damage and serious burns that are nearly impossible to treat, especially when children are the victims.

I'm not a media activist. I'm just a university student who started taking pictures because of a passion for photography and an urge to show people what was happening to my city.

I've never been afraid. I've been injured twice and I'm still taking pictures. Two barrel bombs landed right next to me, 3 shells and rockets, and two days ago, my city was attacked with napalm.

But I'm still here.

 And so long as I'm here, I will continue to  take pictures as a way to to document the crimes committed against the Syrian people and to show the world what we are facing every day. 

I hope that all organizations will raise global awareness to stop the killing in Syria."

Stand with Syrian civilians: www. thesyriacampaign.org

Omran is one of more than 60,000 lives saved by the heroes of the White Helmets. 

Share the story of Syria's heroes. Support them at: https://nobelpeaceprize.whitehelmets.org/en

Video via @AJ+

"The father and his two children were eating breakfast at the time. Just like any other family in Douma, the father was preparing to go to work and the kids to school.

The first attack from the Syrian regime fighter jets happened around 8:30. The second came 5 minutes later. They hit this family's home.   

Childhood in my city is not like childhood in any other place in the world. 

Our children are under siege. They live under daily bombardment. The Regime and Russian forces that continue to bomb and shell our city don't distinguish between children or adults, women or the elderly.

The day starts with warnings from the mosques that there are jets in the sky. People hide out of fear that they will be the next target. Each person is waiting to see if their day to die has arrived.

This has almost become normal for us. Routine. 

I started taking pictures in 2011.  I found myself holding my mobile phone and filming the demonstrations and the regime's repression and crimes against the Syrian people. 

My goal was to let the world see what is actually happening inside of Syria. The killing, the displacement. All I wanted was for the world to see the Syrian people standing up for our human rights. 

I want people to imagine that our children are their children. If they truly believed in human rights and equality, this is what they would do."

Firas Abudallah, Photographer

Thank you Daraya. 

Thank you for showing us that what a small bunch of people can do when standing up against tyranny wherever it comes from. Thank you for showing your resilience when your children were starved, your hospitals bombed, your brothers and sisters disappeared for demanding their freedom and dignity, and when napalm was dropped on what remains of your town.

Thank you for showing that you have more integrity in your little finger than all the silent politicians of the world.

Our profound sadness today is only surpassed by our gratitude for you in showing us what it means to be human.

Thank you Daraya, your resilience is eternal.

(After many years of siege, an agreement with the Syrian government was reached today for rebels and civilians to leave Daraya.  
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/26/world/middleeast/daraya-syria-assad-surrender.html?smid=tw-share )

To read more about Daraya, visit: https://diary.thesyriacampaign.org/daraya-the-town-that-shames-the-world/

For the first time yesterday the UN officially blamed the Assad regime for using chemical weapons against its own people.

Dr. Tennari is one of the many brave medics and rescue workers who saved lives and watched civilians die in a chemical attack on Idlib, Syria in 2015. This is what he had to say:

"When I showed the video I took of three babies from the Taleb family suffocating to death in my hospital, there were tears in the eyes of Security Council members. But some said they didn't have proof of who committed this chemical attack. They said the perpetrators should be stopped and punished, but only once the world knew who was responsible. They know now.

"They must enforce their own resolutions, which call for action under Chapter VII. The Security Council should use force if necessary to ensure that the Assad regime commits no more chemical attacks against civilians and is held accountable." - Dr. Mohammed Tennari, Sarmin field clinic, Idlib.

There have been over 166 chemical attacks in Syria since the first documented attack in 2013.

The resolutions to stop these attacks are in place.
They simply need to be enforced.

Sign the petition: https://medicsunderfire.org/en?source=fb2508

status_message:
The story behind a selfie from the selfless.  

"After Russian airstrikes hit Jeser Al_Shaghour in  Idlib, we ran to help civilians who had been caught in the line of fire. 2 civilians were killed and dozens were injured.

Nothing has changed in Syria. Airstrikes continue to kill civilians. The only thing that has changed is that there are more jets in the sky and more people killing us.

This group has rescued a lot of people. There is a lot of team spirit amongst us.

We took this picture to show the whole world that our mission is to save as many civilians as possible. 

We took this picture while facing death with a smile."

https://nobelpeaceprize.whitehelmets.org/en?source=fb005

The world has lost another White Helmet volunteer. Manar Abu Mohammed was killed last week in the besieged town of Daraya. 

Manar was a hero who often found himself in every possible dangerous situation you can imagine. He died while bringing water to one of the families in besieged Daraya. A regime sniper shot him. The bullet pierced his chest, hitting his heart.

Before joining the White Helmets, he worked at a water tank, delivering water to families throughout the city. It was a way for him to feed himself and support his family who are displaced in a nearby town.

In his free time, he used to plant seeds next to his house so that he could eat. His field was targeted several times by regime airstrikes but this did not stop him from planting again. He was forced to abandon his field when regime forces took it over along with his source of food.

Whenever or wherever there was a fire because of the napalm attacks or airstrikes in Daraya, you would find Manar working hard and with such bravery. He was known for his courage, good heart and he was loved by the people of Daraya.

Today we remember a hero. At times like this it is critical that the White Helmets know that they have support from around the world. Please share his story and sign up to support their nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize. 

https://nobelpeaceprize.whitehelmets.org/en?source=fb003

3 years ago today, 1,347* people in were killed in Eastern Ghouta in a sarin gas attack from the Syrian regime. Artino, a war photographer, rushed to the scene. This is his story. [Artino now works for The Syria Campaign]. 

"My pictures of the attack were used around the world and today they will be used again to mark the 'anniversary'. This is wrong - we do not need one day every year for sadness and then we forget about it again. We need accountability and protection.

I first heard about the attack from my friends on Facebook around 1AM. I had already been injured three times reporting on the sieges in the Ghouta and needed sticks to walk, so I couldn't travel alone and had to wait until the early morning to leave. A friend picked me up on his motorbike and we went to Zamalka, one of the towns that was hit.

We got there and it was like hell. People were running, screaming in the streets and nobody knew what happened - people were trying to use water to treat it but that did nothing.

We went to a field hospital and hundreds of affected people kept coming in. There were so many that doctors could barely check pulses - 'he's dead' - and then they had to move on. Many of those still alive were hallucinating, this is one of the effects of sarin gas. I remember one little girl turning scared to her mother saying, 'Who are you? What do you want?'. I can still see her mother smiling but with fear in her eyes.

I was in shock, crying and shaking too but I was also trained from the front lines and knew I had to help. I spoke to people and took their pictures because even in that chaos, I knew the world needed to see this.

A friend of mine also knew this, that we needed to show this to people, so he brought me to the room of the dead. From the screams of the hospital I went into this quiet room and I couldn't understand, why all these people, all these babies in pyjamas were just lying there sleeping. As a photographer, I see in shots and I started to see more detail, frame by frame in my mind. 

'Why are they silent?' - then the shock, the realization as I saw the dark blue skin, the twisted mouths. I started to shake and cry again and had to leave the room. The chaos of hundreds of people panicking was better than the quiet of the room. I couldn't handle the silence of death, the families dead in pyjamas.

After this, I left and uploaded my photos and tried to come back to help but I was overexposed to the gas and I collapsed. Even from just being near people in the attack, I could hardly breathe and my eyes were swollen and blurry.

I am a photographer, my job is to tell the story and afterwards I had lots of requests for interviews as an eye-witness. What I told them is what I still tell people three years later - this is not 'an event' for you to talk about and then move on. 

After the attack on the 21st, there was a lot of hope in Syria. Obama's 'red line' had been crossed and we thought this meant something would happen, something would change. We waited - for nothing. There have been hundreds of more chemical attacks since, 
people are still losing their families and nothing is being done.

The people of Syria will not be silent about this but world leaders are. If 1,347* can be killed in 2 hours and those with power do nothing, they are not human. They are puppets, toys being moved by others. 

More than a million people in Syria are living under siege today. When these attacks happen to them, they are not an event to talk about and then move on from. Babies have their futures stolen and innocent souls are lost.

The politicians don't give a shit. Yes, they 'remember' but with no action, with no justice, with no freedom or dignity for the people of Syria. Without this, we will carry these memories with no release every day, forever - not just for an 'anniversary'."

To protect Syrian civilians join The Syria Campaign: https://thesyriacampaign.org?source=FB001

*This is the figure from Eastern Ghouta medical office but reports differ. However, there is consensus this figure is most likely an underestimation.

News of the White Helmet's Nobel Peace Prize nomination is hitting the headlines.

Share the good news and sign up in support: https://nobelpeaceprize.whitehelmets.org/en?source=fblaunch

This picture of Omran rescued from a Russian airstrike has been seen by millions. This is the story from Mahmoud Rislan, the photographer who took the picture.

"I live just 300 metres from the attack.  Just after 7PM following the evening prayers we heard the explosions. I rushed there with other three media activists.

The first thing I saw was three bodies on the ground being carried into an ambulance.  Those were the neighbours of Omran's family. The building was totally destroyed -- all six floors were now rubble. 

Then I looked up to see another building half destroyed -- Omran's house. The White Helmet rescue workers climbed the stairs of a building nearby by as the stairs at Omran's house were destroyed. I joined into to help. 

The first survivor they picked up was Omran and I took my camera and started filming. I found it later he was just four year olds.

It was too dark for good footage but I continued and followed him.  The White Helmet carried the boy to the ambulance and laid him on the chair. I kept filming. It is then that I realized how traumatized the boy was and I changed the camera from filming to take a still picture. 

The tears started to drop as I took the photo. Its is not the first time I've cried. I have cried many times while filming traumatized children. I always cry. We war photographers always cry. Last night everyone cried. 

Omran's affected me because he was silent. He didn't cry. He didn't say a word. He was shocked. 

I thought of my 7 days old baby girl. I thought to myself it could be her. It could be any child in Aleppo or Syria. 

Then the White Helmets team continued to rescue the family members. Omar's eldest sister who is 11 looked at me and said please don't film. I turned of my camera and told her "sure my darling I will not". 

Thank god all Omran's family are safe. His mother had some bad injuries in her legs. His father suffered a minor head injury. His 7 year old sister went through a surgical operation this afternoon and she is doing well. 

Today when i woke up to see the whole world using the photo and talking about it. I thought to myself, I hope all photos of children and attacks in Syria go viral so the world know what is life like here. 

If people knew what it was like maybe the war will stop the bombing will stop. 

Maybe Omran and my daughter Amal can live normally like all children in the world.

status_message:
"Khaled Omar is a name you may not recognize but the many people who lives he helped save will never forget it"

Watch and share this beautiful tribute to the 'Miracle Baby' rescuer and fallen hero.

This is how we will remember White Helmet hero Khaled Omar Harah - as a rescuer of children. On the day of this rescue, Khaled lay down exhausted after nine hours of digging. His head was on a pile of rubble when he heard a baby crying beneath. He dug another 13 hours to save him.

Countless people owe their lives to Khaled. For years he ran into danger, emerging from the dust carrying people in his arms or on his shoulders. He was killed yesterday doing what Khaled did - saving others.

May we all strive to be more like Khaled, to serve humanity and be heroes for each other, with humility and grins that can light up a room. Our hearts are with his family and his colleagues. We hope for a speedy recovery for the three White Helmets that were injured yesterday. 

http://www.whitehelmets.org/

Friends, we have some tragic news. Today Khaled was martyred in Aleppo.

Many of us knew Khaled from the 'Miracle Baby' rescue video. Little Mahmoud [pictured] is just on the countless lives Khaled saved. 

Khaled was one of the earliest volunteers of the White Helmets, since joining he has responded to thousands of attacks --- and he made the same choice thousands of times --- to run towards bombs knowing he could be killed. Millions of people around the world have watched the Miracle Baby video and been inspired by Khaled and his bravery. 

Two years ago, Khaled took the first flight of his life to the U.S. where he asked for an end to the the daily massacres -- two years and thousands of attacks later he and his fellow Syrians have still never got an answer. The 'Miracle Baby' video has been screened to dozens of world leaders and to the UN Security Council --- all of whom could have stopped the attacks like the one that killed Khaled if they wanted to.
 
Before the revolution, Khaled was a painter and decorator. Today, like so many others, he died a hero.

Please keep his wife, his two little girls and his fellow volunteers in your thoughts and prayers. 

Humanity lost another hero. We are all heartbroken. 

RIP Khaled. 

https://www.whitehelmets.org/

AMAZING NEWS >> Netflix are releasing a documentary about the the lifesaving heroes of the White Helmets next month.

Putin. This is not Isis.

This is a Russian airstrike on a hospital in East Aleppo. Witnesses report that a vacuum bomb hit the hospital.

This is the third time the hospital has been hit in the last two months. A physician reported this was the biggest explosion he had experienced.

A story to you from Radi Saad - a member of the White Helmets.

"We rushed out after the regime warplanes bombed civilian homes. The devastation was enormous, more than five houses were destroyed and there were dozens of dead and wounded. 

After hours of searching under the rubble for life the death toll had reached twenty, but there was still many people missing, including a woman and a child.

We kept searching for another 24 hours until we found everyone but the two month year old baby. 

 At the very moment that we lost hope that we would ever find the baby, his father found us. 

He had just buried his wife and daughter. 

He spoke to us with a broken heart.

" God bless you and all of your family. 

Please, can you keep searching for my baby, even if you find just a small piece of his body, any piece, I want to bury him near his mother and sister."

At that very moment I did not realize what was happening to me or around me. It could have been because of the scale of the disaster and the large numbers of dead and wounded. Perhaps it was because of the nature of our work and the days we spend enduring such difficulties and fatigue. But I still have no explanation for what I felt when this father made that tragic request. 

When I get back home late at night I remember the situation. I imagine the baby boy's father in front of me. And I can't control myself, my tears fall down and I start to cry. I cry for myself, and for the father who lost all of his family. 

He survived on the hope of finding even a small piece of his baby boy's body."

Support Radi and the White Helmets at https://www.whitehelmets.org/

Children of besieged Aleppo burn tires to fill the skies with smoke to protect their homes from the planes in the sky.

300,000 people are under siege in Aleppo. They are completely trapped on all sides and cut out from food and medicine. Meanwhile, Russian and Syrian regime jets are dropping barrel bombs and missiles on them.

Besieged residents in Aleppo are now making a DIY no-fly zone by burning tires and creating smoke so the fighter jets cannot see the hospitals, schools and homes they usually target.

Yet again Syrians are left saving themselves.

"Most of the families let their children sleep either in the bathroom or a basement, even when they are not fit for a human to stay in, because they feel that they can be protected better in these places,"

status_message:
After more than three years of investigation, the family of US journalist has launched a lawsuit suing the Assad regime for her assassination.

Watch Syrian journalist Rami Jarrah talk about Marie and how the regime has systematically targeted journalists who risk their lives to tell the truth.

Mohammad is the Director of Civil Defense, known as the White Helmets, in the countryside of Damascus. 

"I only sleep for three to four hours a day because of the pressure of my work. Most of the members of the civil defense work  for 24 hours continuously, and rest for 48 hours before their next shift.

When the civil defense was created we had almost 40 volunteers. Today our number has exceeded  400 volunteers.

I've lost 37 people in my life, including members of my team, relatives and friends. They were killed by sniper, shell or missile. It is hard losing people but I remind myself that we do this because we believe that we have a humanitarian duty towards our fellow Syrians.

I myself have been injured several times, one time was nearly fatal. But I promised myself that I would complete this mission no matter what came my way.

One of the hardest situations I've faced was the chemical attack on Eastern Ghouta in August 2013. We mobilized our staff for a full 72 hours. Our job was to rescue civilians and evacuate them and the dead to our base in Douma.

 I still remember that day, Every time we entered houses we saw families affected by poison from the attack. 

It was really painful seeing infants children and babies who died in such a tragic way.

That day, I went back to my house, I held my two children and cried.  I can't imagine losing them. Every time I save a child, it's as am saving my own children.  Every time we lose a child, it's as if we lost our own children. It's hard to keep focus on your mission and not be emotional, we are humans.

On top of that,  we are facing a lot of difficulties due to the siege on Eastern Ghouta.

We've lost equipment including ambulances, fire trucks and heavy equipment many times. We lost one to two vehicles in every civil defense base due to the attacks that targets civil defense teams as soon as they enter the scene and try to rescue people.

And we can't find the equipment and maintenance we need or get them delivered from abroad. Most of the time we can't even afford to maintain the equipment because of the siege.  We use the machines we have even if they don't function very well.  

When we do find what we need, the prices are very high. But we have no other choice but to buy them. We need them to save people's lives. This is our duty.

With every life we save, we forget all the difficulties that come our way.

Photo Credit: Mohammed Abdullah

No where is safe for Syrians today. Not even their homes, schools or hospitals.

But contrary to what you might read in the papers, Isis and other extremist groups are not the biggest threat to civilians.

The regime of Bashar al-Assad and its allies - including Russia - are responsible for the vast majority of civilian deaths.  

Now the United States has decided to deepen its ties with Russia, despite evidence that Russia has used illegal incendiary weapons against civilian populations inside Syria. 

People say that Russia and the US disagree on Syria. But they seem to agree on their disregard for civilians.

status_message:
Like many of you we at The Syria Campaign are still reeling at the news of the tragic loss of Jo Cox.

Jo was not just a phenomenal humanitarian and human being, she was also the stand out champion of Syrian civilians.

No other political figure was so keen to listen to Syrian civilians and raise their demands to the world.

Whether it was breaking the sieges or stopping the barrel bombs, Jo always knew what needed to be said, and had the bravery to say it.

We will miss her at The Syria Campaign. But she will be missed by millions of Syrian civilians, who have lost their most vocal and passionate defender.

Rest in peace, Jo.
A bit of of good news from Aleppo: the children's hospital damaged two weeks ago has reopened with 5 new incubators.

This month, the UN finally reached Daraya with food baskets. Residents of the besieged city had not seen an aid delivery in over three years.  However, due to indiscriminate regime airstrikes, people had to wait for days for the aid to be distributed. It was simply too dangerous for them to gather in one place. 

As the local council of Daraya described it, 'Pound-for-pound, the amount of explosives dropped on the city far exceeds that of humanitarian aid delivered.'

This is what one woman in Daraya had to say. 

"On June 9, aid finally came into Daraya after four years of living under siege.

On June 10, regime barrel bombs were raining down on our heads.

Aid entered after four years of siege. My husband was one of the volunteers helping load the aid into the warehouses. The aid is not enough to meet the needs of civilians. It was only enough for 2,500 civilians.  There are 8,000 of us.

Yesterday and today the warehouses storing the aid were targeted. And that's in addition to the indiscriminate, incessant, regime shelling they're carrying out deliberately to make it impossible to distribute the aid to civilians.
 
That the UN has been distributing that paper which is supposed to say what aid they've brought in. We still haven't been able to do an inventory to check how much the regime took from it.

But because the aid isn't enough for all civilians, we've decided to re-distribute the food baskets so that every family has something. We hope there's enough so that each family gets half a food basket.

We're calling for the siege to be lifted off Daraya and a ceasefire, an end to the barrel bombs and the surface-to-surface missiles."
link_name: Photos from The Syria Campaign's post

status_message: The same government that's keeping one million civilians under siege is being effectively put in charge of the UN's biggest aid operation in history. And the consequence of that is millions of the world's people, the most vulnerable, aren't receiving the aid they so desperately need.  Take a look at this interview about our #Takingsides report.

The UN has done so much good in the world. But its aid operation in Syria has gone very, very wrong. 

Today we release a new report "Taking Sides: How the UN lost impartiality, independence and neutrality in Syria".

After speaking to more than 50 humanitarians, including senior former and current UN staff, this report details how we arrived at the situation we're at today, where the distribution of billions of dollars of aid gets largely dictated by the Assad regime, where hundreds have died of starvation only minutes away from UN warehouses full of aid.

The aid system in Syria is utterly broken and civilians are paying the price.

What is needed is not international pressure to get one or two trucks into an area besieged for years, but a fundamental reset of how aid works.

There are more than 55 Syrian groups backing the report's recommendations and more are joining every day. They include the Syria Civil Defence (the White Helmets), the Syrian Network for Human Rights, the Violations Documentation Center and many more.

These groups together with The Syria Campaign are calling on the UN Secretary General, Ban Ki-moon to take control by setting clear conditions on the UN's relationship with the Syrian government. This must include the ability to deliver aid impartially to those who need it most, regardless of what side they're on. If this fails, the UN must suspend cooperation with the Syrian government.

Some inside the UN fear that if they take a tougher stance with the Syrian government they'll get their visas withdrawn and they'll be kicked out the country. This isn't true. As David Miliband, head of the International Rescue Committee says, "the Assad regime can't afford to kick the UN out of Damascus. The UN is feeding so many of [Assad's] own people."

A stronger UN in Syria will mean millions more civilians get the food and medicine they need.

Please join the petition to Ban Ki-moon calling on him to set red lines: https://act.thesyriacampaign.org/sign/stop-taking-sides/

You can download and read the full report here: http://takingsides.thesyriacampaign.org

(Artwork by the incredible Tammam Azzam - Art)
As the bombs drop on Idlib the heroes of the White Helmets rescue another baby forgotten by the world.

''We expected that it would happen one day, and today is that day. There are now only 18 incubators left in Eastern Aleppo.''

This morning, a regime airstrike hit the street outside the Children's Hospital that Dr. Hatem runs in Aleppo, supported by Independent Doctors Association.

Nine premature and newborn babies were at the hospital. The priority was to get the babies downstairs so that they would not suffer the dire consequences of breathing in all the dust.

''It was a horrible moment. The nurses were trampling each other to rush the babies to the basement, while many of them started to cry. As my staff moved the incubators, I went to tell the people in the waiting room to leave the hospital. I ordered them to "Leave now! There might be a second attack.''

One of the worst fears that immediately follows a strike is the possibility of another.

The hospital is now out of service, like so many other hospitals inside Aleppo today.

All of the babies thankfully survived.

And Dr. Hatem refuses to give up hope.

''We will repair the Children's Hospital, and we will reopen it.

I want every president to imagine that one of these newborns were his own son or daughter. Whatever they would do for their sons if they were bombed, they must do for these newborns.''
Last week an aid delivery reached besieged Daraya for the first time since 2012. It contained mosquito nets instead of food.

"Starving Syrian children cannot eat more empty words and hollow promises … It is shocking and completely unacceptable that the trucks are prevented from bringing any food."

Yesterday an aid convoy entered the besieged town of Daraya Syria for the first time since 2012. However, the trucks that came in were nearly empty and did not contain any food. Clearly, what was brought  in yesterday will not not meet the needs of people in Daraya. And neither will a one-off delivery of food. While yesterday proved that some aid can get in when the international community has some backbone, it is time to show more of it. Syrians cannot afford to wait any longer. The international community needs to push for sustained, unconditional, and unimpeded aid access to civilians in need.#breakthesieges

In 213 days the most powerful countries in the world could hardly get these traffic lights to flicker off red. Is anybody surprised that the Syrian peace process is dead/dying?

>> URGENT APPEAL FROM MADEA >>

https://act.thesyriacampaign.org/sign/protect-marea/

" When I spoke to my fellow doctor Dr Abdel Rahman last night, he said that Isis fighters had reached his hospital's car park. They wanted to take the medical staff as hostages.

The Free Hospital in the northern town of Marea has two specialisms -- one is a surgical facility and the other for women and children. For years its 36 medical staff have worked to provide healthcare for the 12,000 civilians left in the town -- over half are women and children.

When I visited the hospital last year, the situation was critical. I contacted US Ambassador Samantha Power and told her that Isis were only a few kilometers away.

Now the hospital could be overrun any minute. Please send an urgent message to Ambassador Power and the US administration to protect this hospital, now.

https://act.thesyriacampaign.org/sign/protect-marea/

The town of Mareaa in northern Syria is being attacked on all sides. By Isis, by the Assad regime and also by Kurdish forces. Isis hate this town particularly because it represents a non-jihadist view of Syria. The people in Marea detest extremism and there are no extremists there. They want to be free of the Assad regime and groups like Isis.

The US and others have done nothing so far to protect this town. The messages I get over Whatsapp from the head doctor Dr Abdel Rahman are heartbreaking. If the world cannot protect his hospital and patients from Isis then nobody knows what will happen.

Ambassador Power has long championed the voices of Syria's medics, now is the time to really prove it. This week we saw published photos of US soldiers on the ground in Syria fighting Isis. But why have they turned their back on Marea? Why are they indifferent to this hospital on the front line?

https://act.thesyriacampaign.org/sign/protect-marea/

Dr Zaher Sahloul 
Chairman of the Syrian American Medical Society's Global Response

Interviewer: If you could make three wishes what would they be?

"Stop the fighting, have aid come, and to see my relatives."

Film from Syria Direct

This is Abu Haitham. 

A grandfather. A farmer.  A family man.

We loved him in besieged Daraya.  

Abu Haitham was not just a survivor of this siege but was selfless, always thinking of others. He would give what little milk he could get from his three goats to those most in need. He gave priority to the injured over his own grandchildren. And like so many of the other residents of our town, his family survived on only one meal a day provided by a charity kitchen. Yet Abu Haitham would still find the energy to go collect grass in the nearby fields.

On May 12, Abu Haitham, like so many others who have been waiting for three years for a drop of food to reach our town, was expecting the United Nations to bring food and medicine. 

Abu Haitham and his son Saleh left around 8am in the morning and waited all day. But the promised aid never came. And around 4pm Abu Haitham and Saleh gave up and left to take care of their goats.
 
But then the mortar struck. The Assad regime fired mortars on the town after refusing to let the aid in. Abu Haitham and Saleh lost their lives to senseless violence. They lost their lives after learning to cope with the conditions of a brutal siege that has left us inching closer to starvation every day. 

Abu Haitham left behind his wife, a daughter in law and his grandchildren. They have no support now and like so many of us, have all given up on the international community and the idea of help.

In our eyes, Daraya was once an international city - we had trade, agriculture and manufacturing. We were well known farmers and our grapes were famous across the whole country.  

What has happened to it now? And why has the world abandoned us?

-- Abu Sabri

هذا النصر الذي حققه الضغط الجماعي

علق ستيفين ديمستورا، مبعوث الأمم المتحدة في سوريا على إعلان إنزال المساعدات جواً يوم أمس.

بأنه

قبل شهر فقط كان من المستحيل التحدث عن هذا الموضوع " "

والذ حصل انه قبل شهر بدأنا مع بعض بالضغط على الأطراف الدولية ( الولايات المتحدة الأميريكية - روسيا - و باقي الأطراف التي من المفترض ان توقف العنف في سوريا ) والذين طلبنا منهم التدخل بإنزال المساعدات جواً للمناطق المحاصرة بسبب إستمرار نظام الأسد بمنع وصول المساعدات وإدخالها براً.

الكثيرين علقوا بأنه من المستحيل ان يتحقق ذلك.

الأمم المتحدة أعلنت بعدم إستطاعتها القيام بذلك.

باقي المنظمات صرحت بأنه من المستحيل القيام بذلك.

ولكن بجهود الجميع استطعنا تحقيق ذلك ومافعلناه كان التالي :.

نشرنا مناشدات من نساء داريا و المجلس المحلي في المدينة .

قمنا بإرسال أكثر من 13,000 بريد إلكتروني للدول الرئيسية في بيان المجموعة الدولية لدعم سوريا ISSG

العديد قاموا بالتواصل المباشر مع مكاتب بعثات هذه الدول في مدينتي نيويورك و جنيف

قمنا بتنظيم رسالة مفتوحة موقعة من أكثر من 25 من السياسيين الرئيسيين الأوروبيين

ارسلنا العديد من الدعوات المرسلة من السوريين في الداخل الى الإعلام العالمي

منظمة النساء الآن من أجل التنمية تحدثت مع الصحافة و قدمت العديد من القصص المأساوية لنساء يعشن تحت الحصار .

رسالة مفتوحة من النساء في مركز "نساء الآن" في داريا أدت لعديد من التظاهرات النسائية في الداخل السوري و استجاب لهذه الرسالة عدد كبير من البرلمانيين والنساء في أوروبا الذين تضامنوا برفع صوتهم لدعم مطالب النساء في داريا

مجموعة من أصدقاء سوريا نظموا وقفة تضامنية في المملكة المتحدة متضمنة بيانات للناشطين عبروا عن دعمهم لعملية إنزال المساعدات جواً

العديد من النشاطات بالإضافة لماذكر سابقاً

تم البارحة طلب إنزال المساعدات جواً من قبل بيان المجموعة الدولية لدعم سوريا ISSG وذلك في حال إستمرار نظام الأسد في منع دخول المساعدات براً قبل الأول من حزيران ، و تم الطلب من الامم المتحدة تنظم جسر من المساعدات الجوية لجميع المناطق المحاصرة في سوريا

قال أحمد من داريا :"لا يمكننا أن نحكم أو نحتفل حتى نرى المساعدات بأعيننا. كنا متأملين خلال الشهرين الأخيرين من السلام، ولكن نحن الآن نتعرض للقصف مرة أخرى. محاصيل القمح لدينا حرقت بسبب القصف. النظام يحاول ان يجعل الحصار أكثر صعوبة ".

A number of blasts have killed more than 145 civilians today in Tartus and Jableh - two coastal cities in Regime controlled areas . A bus station and hospital were hit and paramedics are reported among the injured. Isis claimed responsibility for the attacks. 

No matter who is doing the killing a civilian is a civilian is a civilian. All the attacks must stop.

This is a victory for public pressure!

"We would have never talked about it just a month ago." - Staffan De Mistura, UN Syria envoy on the airdrops announcement yesterday.

A month ago together we started pushing the International Syria Support Group (the US, Russia and others supposedly helping to stop the violence) saying they should conduct airdrops of aid to besieged areas if the Assad regime continues to block land access.

Many said it would never happen.

- The UN said publicly they couldn't do it
- Key countries said publicly they wouldn't do it
- Other organisations said it'd be impossible

But together we dug in.

- We published appeals from the women of Daraya and the Daraya Local Council
- We sent 13,000+ emails to key countries on the ISSG
- Many jumped on the phone and called these country missions in NY and Geneva
- We organised a public letter from more than 25 key European politicians
- We pushed calls from Syrians out to the media far and wide
-  Women Now for Development spoke to the press and broke the stories of women living under siege
- An open letter from women at the Women Now centre in Daraya mobilised protests across Syria and received solidarity from parliamentarians and women in Europe who raised their voice in support of their demands
- Friends from Syria Solidarity UK organised protests and statements from activists in support of airdrops
- and much more besides..

Well yesterday the ISSG called for it. If Assad doesn't open the road by 1st of June, they are calling on the UN to set up an air bridge to all besieged areas.

Ahmad from Daraya said "We can't judge or celebrate until we see the aid with our own eyes. We were hopeful during these last two months of peace but now we're being shelled again. Our wheat harvests are being burned. The regime is trying to make the siege even more difficult."

That's why this is only a first step. We need to make sure the UN don't ask for permission they'll never get. We need to make sure countries who are part of the ISSG use all means to get this aid in.

And we need to make sure that this is movement towards ensuring sustained access to all areas across Syria. Airdrops are a sticking plaster, they're not a solution to the problem. No civilians should be going hungry because their government is blocking aid.

There is so much bleak news on Syria, and so much of it eclipses this little bit of good news. But let's celebrate this important win and use it to energise us. 

If this is possible then we must work together to achieve much, much more.

We have seen the hint of a backbone from the international community that everyone assumed had disappeared. We must keep pushing to break the sieges, stop the barrel bombs and unlock the dungeons holding so many political prisoners.

Well done everyone. Onwards.

"We're exhausted but not weak"

>> EMERGENCY REPORT FROM DARAYA >> 

Yesterday: A father and son were killed by Regime shelling whilst standing waiting for an aid convoy --- they had not seen an aid delivery for 1301 days. 

Here's the story of the day's failures: 

Yesterday, the UN FINALLY drove aid trucks to Daraya -- a besieged town just 20 mins drive from UN HQ.  Unbelievably the convoy contained NO food -- just some medicines as that was all the Regime allowed. Once the UN reached the town the Regime removed all the medicine. The UN was stuck at the checkpoint calling Russia to ask them to call the Syrian Regime to let them in as they had agreed. This phone tag happened in the middle of the biggest operation in the UN's history. 

Hours later, people in the town were informed that the convoy had been denied entry and would turn back. 

Civilians were gathered at the entrance to the town since morning, waiting for the aid trucks to enter. While some went home later in the day upset at the wait and the lack of food on the convoy, others remained. As soon as the convoy left they became the targets of the Syrian regime's shelling -- A father and son were killed and five others injured. 

The father and son should never have been standing for hours waiting for food. With the denial of access today and the shelling of those gathered at the collection point, it is clear that the UN and its donors' failures have put malnourished people in the firing line. Today is a dark day in the history of the UN and the world. 

Break the silence on sieges. Share this story.

Dear friends,

I am Dr Hatem, the director of the Children's Hospital in Aleppo. 

Last night, 27 staff and patients were killed in an airstrike on Al Quds Hospital nearby. My friend Dr Muhammad Waseem Maaz (pictured), the city's most qualified paediatrician, was killed in the attack. 

He used to work at our Children's Hospital during the day and then he'd go to Al Quds Hospital to attend to emergencies overnight. 

Dr Maaz and I used to spend six hours a day together. He was friendly, kind and he used to joke a lot with the whole staff. He was the loveliest doctor in our hospital.

I'm in Turkey now, and he was supposed to visit his family here after I returned to Aleppo. He hadn't seen them in four months.

Dr Maaz stayed in Aleppo, the most dangerous city in the world, because of his devotion to his patients. Hospitals are often targeted by government and Russian air forces. 

Days before Dr Maaz's life was taken, an airstrike hit only 200 metres away from our hospital. When the bombing intensifies, the medical staff run down to the ground floor of the hospital carrying the babies' incubators in order to protect them.

Like so many others, Dr Maaz was killed for saving lives. Today we remember Dr Maaz's humanity and his bravery. Please share his story so others may know what medics in Aleppo and across Syria are facing. 

The situation today is critical - Aleppo may soon come under siege. We need the world to be watching.

Thank you for keeping us in your thoughts,

Dr Hatem

Aleppo is under fierce attack. Yesterday, the most senior paediatrician in opposition areas was killed by another targeted attack on a hospital by Assad regime/Russian forces. The world has the means to stop this, but we're sitting back and watching it happen.

A letter to you from Loubna about the besieged town of Daraya: 

"I'm a Syrian women's rights activist and I want to tell you about the town of Daraya. 

Every minute, every hour, the 8,500 people trapped in the town are inching closer to starvation. We need food and medicine to reach them before the unthinkable happens. 

We are asking for aid to be sent to the town immediately, and if it can't be driven there, then it must be airdropped from the sky. 

The people with the power to do this are your politicians. They won't listen to us, but you have influence over them. Please send an urgent message to your leaders now:

https://act.thesyriacampaign.org/sign/airdrop-aid-syria-now/

I know what it's like to experience hunger. 

I lived under siege in Eastern Ghouta in Damascus for two and a half years. Still, compared to Daraya now, our situation was a blessing. We were able to grow some vegetables to survive. We would grind animal feed and mix it with water to make 'bread'.  

But in Daraya they don't have anything. 

I last spoke to people in Daraya two days ago to see what their needs were. The men listed the usual items like protein-rich food, and medicine and vaccines. 

But the needs of the women were very specific and detailed. 

Their daily struggles are different. They don't have sanitary pads. They use cloths instead but then there's no clean water to sanitise the cloths afterwards. They need lice shampoo and soap. They need milk and milk bottles to be sent in for their babies. They can't breastfeed because they're malnourished.  

I'm seven months pregnant now and I think about the women and kids in Daraya constantly. 

The woman who runs our network's centre in Daraya has had two miscarriages during the siege due to malnutrition and lack of medical care. One was at three months and the other one was at six months. 

We can do something. I don't want us a few weeks from now to be crying over images of people who have starved to death and say "I wish we had done something before". The time is now. Please call on world governments to airdrop food into Daraya today:

https://act.thesyriacampaign.org/sign/airdrop-aid-syria-now/

Thank you, 

Lubna

Women Now for Development "SFD" (known previously as Soriyat For Development) is a Syrian non-profit organization dedicated to deepening and strengthening women's role in Syrian and host communities by enhancing their political, social, economic and cultural participation.

status_message:
An URGENT letter to you from Ibrahim Kholany in Daraya

"Dear friends,

I am writing to you from the besieged town of Daraya.

They call our town the school of the peaceful uprising. But right now our people are beginning to starve and some are resorting to eating grass to survive. We have been under brutal siege by Assad's regime for over three years.

Yesterday the UN announced that it has the regime's permission to deliver aid to besieged areas, but Daraya was not on the list. We have not received any aid for over 1,000 days.

We were promised a month ago by the United States and the UN that it would only be a matter of days before convoys of food and medicine would enter. But still there has been nothing.

We are being punished for daring to rise up peacefully for our freedom and dignity. There are no extremists like Isis here, or Nusra. Those defending our neighbourhoods are all locals, protecting the streets from a government that has tortured, gassed and bombed us and our families.

What scares the regime is the strength and legitimacy of our community. Our democratically-elected council is a threat to Bashar al-Assad's dictatorship.

We respect all international agreements that have been made on Syria. But we cannot enforce them. That is why we are calling on you, friends around the world, to push the UN, United States and other key countries to uphold these agreements and deliver food and medicine to our town immediately.

Please send a message to key negotiators on humanitarian aid, demanding they keep their promises and break the siege on Daraya

https://act.thesyriacampaign.org/sign/save-daraya

Thank you for standing with us,

Ibrahim
Member of the Local Council of Daraya"

URGENT! The most powerful countries meeting to get aid into besieged areas just announced that the Assad regime is STILL blocking aid to several areas, including the town of Daraya where some are being forced to eat grass to survive.

We need to push urgently to make sure that we don't have people starving to death like in Madaya. Please send an urgent email to the negotiators saying this is totally unacceptable and they must get that food and medicine in.

"There are no words worthy of the Syrian woman and all she has done, but I want to tell her that everything she has done is amazing."

Celebrating International Women's Day with a tribute from Razan Zaitouneh to Syrian women. 

Razan Zaitouneh is an activist and human rights lawyer who was kidnapped with her colleagues over two years ago because of their brilliant work human rights work -- their whereabouts is still unknown. Today we celebrate her heroism and the heroism of all Syrian women who have powered change and served their community through horrendous attacks and abuses.

On International Women's Day we're celebrating some of the bravest women on the planet -- the female White Helmets who rush towards the bombs to rescue others. Formerly students, teachers, office workers -- now these women save lives. 

Hasnaa Shawaf from Idlib joined because ""I desperately wanted to help, I couldn't just sit and do nothing."

Nojod from Daraa "I am not scared; we're used to it, I joined the White Helmets because our work is humanitarian and it's a neutral institute which serves all the people during bombings and in any other crisis."

Share their story. Share hope.

https://www.whitehelmets.org/

When the Syrian ceasefire was first announced, there was widespread skepticism that it would even last a day. The Russians have been bombing the hell out of Aleppo for over a month, they are on their way to decimating the opposition and shoring up Assad - why would they stop now? 

Only a paltry amount of aid has reached the besieged areas that need it most while Russian and Syrian forces are still trying to regain as much territory as they can. But for the first time in years, bombs have stopped raining on civilian communities. People are able to walk in the streets without barrel bombs, shells or shrapnel falling on them.

Next week, it will be five years since the Syrian peaceful uprising began. This all started when ordinary folk went out and held up banners asking for reforms, freedom, justice and democracy. When Assad turned his forces on the opposition, Syria descended into chaos. Out of the instability, extremist groups were able to proliferate. 

For far too long, Syria has just been known in international news headlines for ISIS and the refugee crisis. And because of the complexity of this war, civilian voices were silenced and the nonviolent struggle mostly dismissed as nonexistent. 

This past week, you would think that Syrians would have taken advantage of the relative peace and quiet to recuperate, to run errands or even to try escaping their besieged hometowns and seeking better lives elsewhere. 

Syrians have been subjected to five years of unrelenting punishing violence, the kind of violence that can irrevocably break a people. Surely, the world thought they must have given up on their yearning for basic human rights by now. 

But, instead, civilians burst out into the streets of Syria in droves reigniting the original peaceful uprising with such renewed vigor and such an unexpected joie de vivre! Exiled Syrians watching from abroad, in utter disbelief, are tearing up at the mere sight of their country men and women resuming a cherished revolution with the elated chanting, the joyful communal dancing and the taunting slogans addressed to Assad and his clique.

More importantly, we're back to the unwavering faith that what Syrians took incommensurable risks to ignite isn't over just yet.

We Syrians need your prayers and support more than ever. We are not doomed to enter the annals of a tragic history. In a hundred years, people will look back on this era and they will say that we have achieved the impossible.

Yours truly,
Hania

URGENT: Save the ceasefire 

A key part of the ceasefire agreement is that aid would be delivered to areas under horrific 'starvation sieges' at the start of the ceasefire. Yet the Assad regime continuing to block access for aid trucks. 

In less than 24 hours, the most powerful countries in the world that make up the international "Humanitarian Task Force" on Syria will meet in Geneva to negotiate aid delivery. These are our representatives and we need to tell them they must do more to get aid to the million people living under siege. 

Sign the petition to let them know we're watching and expect progress. 

http://act.thesyriacampaign.org/sign/save-ceasefire/

URGENT: Meeting in 24 hours

The partial ceasefire in Syria is saving lives but right now it's extremely fragile. The Assad regime is blocking aid trucks from going into besieged areas. This is a major breach of the current ceasefire and threatens the whole agreement.

Tomorrow, in less than 24 hours, the most powerful countries in the world that make up the international "Humanitarian Task Force" on Syria will meet in Geneva to negotiate aid delivery.

These are diplomats and politicians that respond to public scrutiny and together have sway over the Assad regime. If they feel the pressure from the world outside their negotiation room, they will push harder to get this aid in. It's the best hope of keeping this fragile ceasefire alive.

Take a moment to sign this urgent petition to the Humanitarian Task Force to ensure aid delivery to besieged areas today: http://act.thesyriacampaign.org/sign/save-ceasefire/

In the last week Dr Khaled has left Madaya after receiving a series of death threats. He was told that armed groups were trying to kill him, "My friend advised me to leave because he had been told there was a direct threat to my life. I also received an anonymous phone call from a man who said he would assassinate me."
So he gathered all his savings and paid off the officers manning the checkpoints. His wife and daughter went to Damascus and he fled in the opposite direction towards Lebanon. He had to walk for three days and nights. Dr Khaled Mohammed is currently in hiding but his family are safe.

Two years ago today the UN Security Council passed Resolution 2139 which banned barrel bombs and other indiscriminate weapons. They promised to take further steps if their resolution was violated.

Two years later 19,974 barrel bombs have been dropped on schools, homes, hospitals and bakeries. Nothing has been done.

Syrians need protection from all bombs.

Data from Syrian Network for Human Rights - الشبكة السورية لحقوق الإنسان

Sunday was one of the bloodiest days in Syria's conflict with 140 people killed. A string of bomb blasts struck the city of Homs and the southern Damascus suburb of Sayyida Zeinab, named after a shrine revered by Shiites.

In Homs, 57 people were killed in a double car bombing while four blasts killed 83 people in the suburb of Sayyida Zeinab. ISIS claimed responsibility for both attacks. Both areas that were targeted yesterday are homes to religious minorities that are reviled and considered infidels by ISIS.

All the killing must stop from all sides.

There are one million civilians living under siege in Syria today. Do you ever wonder how people have been surviving under siege, deprived of the most basic necessities, day in day out? Civilians have had to rely on their inner resources, but they've also been leaning on their close knit communities and neighbors.

We are bringing you a series of true stories from besieged areas that demonstrate Syrians' resilience and spirit of resistance. Some will make you laugh, some will make you cry.

Here's the first story:

In besieged Daraya, you don't throw away stale bread because it's something of a rare commodity. But cooking it gets a lot more complicated when some unwelcome guests show up.

status_message:
Last night, world powers agreed to get aid to towns under siege and a ceasefire between all groups except Al Qaeda and Isis. 

There's just one, gaping, hole in the proposal.

The ceasefire doesn't stop Russia's bombing campaign, which has destroyed schools and hospitals far away from any Isis areas.

Russia is now the biggest killer of civilians in Syria and according to the Syrian Network for Human Rights has killed more than the Assad regime, Al Qaeda and Isis combined in 2016.

Syrians desperately want a ceasefire and an end to the violence. 
But they want a real ceasefire, one that includes these Russian attacks on civilians too.

Join The Syria Campaign to push for the protection of Syrian civilians: https://thesyriacampaign.org/
The Russian invasion of Syria has left hundreds dead and thousands displaced from their homes. The US is meeting Russia today in Munich to talk peace. Do they still want the same outcomes?

What will the US and Russia shake hands on today?

The besieged town of Madaya was prominently featured in international news as dozens of civilians succumbed to their deaths due to starvation. 

Here's an even more shocking fact: Madaya is not the only besieged town in Syria. There are a million Syrian civilians stuck in besieged areas across the country. They suffer from extreme hunger and malnutrition-related illnesses while undelivered UN aid often sits minutes away. 

The Assad regime is blocking access to these areas as it enforces a "kneel or starve" war tactic. In the meantime, the international community's inaction has led to thousands of deaths from starvation. 

Here are seven essential facts you need to know.
link_name: Seven myths about sieges in Syria debunked

status_message:
We know that the money you raise today in London is unlikely to reach us or alleviate the suffering in our besieged areas. The UN, and its partners, have not been able to deliver the aid that we need. The UN humanitarian organisations have not been seen in our towns for months, sometimes even years. Nineteen more people have died of starvation in Madaya since the last UN convoys pulled out of the town on the 16th of January. It is an undeniable tragedy that the billions of dollars in aid you pledge today is not going to reach those that need it the most.

In order to really help the people in Syria we are calling on you to do the following.
link_name: Letter from besieged Syrians to governments at the London Donors' Conference

People often ask why sieges are happening. This is why.

Break the silence, break the siege: www.breakthesieges.org

Rescue workers, medics, teachers, mothers, children, tunnel diggers, farmers, media activists, fathers. 

Under siege everyone plays their part in helping others survive -- often risking their own lives in the process. 

Stand with these heroes and #breakthesieges https://breakthesieges.org/en

Moadamiya has been under siege since 2012. The last time the town received any aid was in July 2014 when the UN delivered some packages yet is it just miles from the UN offices in Damascus. 

The Syrian regime uses sieges to starve citizens into submission. A hungry person lacks the energy and will to envision any kind of different future. As one Syrian from Douma explained: "When you besiege a community, you transform their whole raison d'etre from a civil struggle for their rights to a struggle for survival on a day-to-day basis. This is the point of the siege, to neutralise the power of the people.To reduce them to a starving quivering mass rather than a community capable of resistance."

Yet, against all odds, Syrians stood their ground. They still refuse to bow, they still refuse to leave their homes and they refuse to capitulate. Syrians are still clinging to their original demands even while starving.This video made by media activist Dani Qabbani is a testament to that spirit of resistance.

This is life under siege, where hunger is used as a weapon of war.

Break the silence, break the siege: www.breakthesieges.org

Stephen O'Brien and UN OCHA are finally speaking out. Public pressure is working. From this morning's Telegraph:

"We must be guided by the humanitarian imperative, and acknowledge the failure of negotiations over four years to secure the necessary access to these besieged areas," wrote Stephen O'Brien, the UN under-secretary general for humanitarian affairs. "My advice would be that all options be considered as we must find a way to break this impasse."

Keep up the pressure on the UN. Break the silence, break the sieges: www.breakthesieges.org
link_name: Air drop food to starving Syrians, UN tells Britain

Rescue workers, doctors, teachers, farmers, and ordinary people - these people have risked their lives for their communities under siege. They are the ones who try and get the next dose of dialysis, dig people up from under the rubble, keep children in school or find a way to get people the meals that they need. They can do everything in their power to try and keep people alive, but without food it is simply impossible. 

Break the silence, break the siege: www.breakthesieges.org/en?source=fbheroes

"By allowing the regime to veto aid to civilians in areas outside its control, you have allowed the UN to become a political tool of the war. Aid should go to those who need it most, without regard to
politics. This is why people here think the siege is as much by the UN as it is by the regime."

Rescue workers, doctors, teachers, and farmers are the ones risking their lives to save others under siege. They can do everything in their power to try and keep people alive, but without food it is simply impossible. Today hundreds of these heroes wrote to the UN asking them why they are allowing the Syrian regime to block aid from reaching 99% of the *million* people under siege.

Raqqa Is Being Slaughtered Silently (RBSS) is a Syrian citizen journalist collective whose members are working tirelessly, at great personal risk, to report on what's happening inside Raqqa, the Islamic State's self-proclaimed capital in Syria. Many RBSS members have been brutally murdered for daring to show the truth. In fact, one of their leaders was just assassinated in his apartment in Turkey last month. Yet, despite the significant risks, they continue to report on events in the ISIS-held province, from the mundane to the most horrific human rights violations such as beheadings, rape and crucifixions.

These brave young men and women face execution at any time for leaking out images and reports from the tightly controlled northern province that has been under ISIS control for two years. Foreign journalists who don't have access to Raqqa often rely on those reports to find out what daily life in Raqqa is like.

RBSS shows the complexities of life in Raqqa: many citizens have reluctantly joined ISIS because they are often not given any other choice. RBSS chose to stand strong and resist the slow creep of ISIS by exposing their flagrant abuses at every turn. 

This year, they were honored with the Committee to Protect Journalists' International Press Freedom Award.

One of their members walked on stage with the flag of the Syrian revolution wrapped around his shoulders and gave the following acceptance speech upon receiving the award in New York.
link_name: Undercover heroes win top award for exposing Isis

status_message: Women political prisoners often come across prostitutes and drug dealers in Adra prison. Once they're released, these women are quick to distance themselves from women of ill repute (by judging them) and to establish their credentials as respected activists and public figures. But women political prisoners should not be so quick to ostracize less unfortunate women just because they're uneducated or work in prostitution, says Maysah Saleh. At the end of the day, they're all victims of the same unjust legal system.
link_name: A women's prison in Syria: prostitutes are no less worthy of fair treatment than political prisoners

"BREAKING: Russian airstrike hits our location in the kalaseh area of central Aleppo which is a civilian populated area during our trip in the city. as a result a number of casualties. Most of you know the city of Palmyra for its beautiful ruins and temples that ISIS destroyed when they stormed the city last May, but did you know that it's also the site of a state-run notorious prison where many Syrians disappeared?
Many argue that the prison should never have been destroyed because it provides evidence of state crimes. By blowing up this edifice that strikes terror in the hearts of Syrians, ISIS did the Syrian regime a huge favor.

On Tuesday a field hospital in Sarmin, Idlib was targeted by Russian airstrikes using air-to-surface missiles. As medical workers and civilians rushed to rescue patients the hospital was struck again. 10 civilians and two doctors were killed. 

Dr. Tennari, the Director of the hospital described what it's like to save lives in these conditions: 

"When I am in the hospital, I feel like I am sitting on a bomb. It is only a matter of time until it explodes. It is wrong- a hospital should not be the most dangerous place. I wish I could say that targeting a hospital in Syria is unique, but is not. The field hospital I direct in Sarmin has been targeted and hit by airstrikes more than 18 times - by the Syrian government and now by the Russian government. 

We've seen too many civilians and medical staff die in our hospital to count. The hardest part is knowing that these attacks will happen again - the UN and international community needs to enforce their own resolutions and commitments to upholding international law, and prevent more attacks against hospitals."

Join us to campaign to stop the violence: www.thesyriacampaign.org

On Saturday another White Helmet hero was killed for saving lives. 

The White Helmets were evacuating civilians from the village of Atshan in Hama which had been subject to intense bombing from the air.  During the evacuation a White Helmet truck was targeted by an airstrike killing Muhammad Abdo Barquomi.

Later that day the White Helmet centre in Atshan was struck by a bomb. Luckily the team were in a shelter so they survived but all their equipment was destroyed. Shortly after Atshan village was taken by the Syrian regime. 

Below is Muhammad Abdo Barquomi disposing of a naval mine just days ago. 

Many White Helmets look at this page. Please leave comments of support for these brave heroes who are under attack.

The results of the first ever survey of Syrian refugees in Europe are pretty revealing. 

It might seem that the people struggling in boats across perilous waters or jumping over barbed wire fences really want to be in Europe. But they don't. Syrians want to go home to the country they know and love. The problem is with the violence raging they can't.

Have a look at the full results here: https://diary.thesyriacampaign.org/what-refugees-think/

On Friday, October 2, a SAMS-supported field hospital in northern Hama was hit by shelling from a Russian airstrike that severely damaged the facility. This attack injured 2 nurses and a hospital guard and caused major damage to the facility's medication supply, the electric generator, and our only ambulance. The hospital has been shut down as result of the destruction.

Today a White Helmet, Issam al-Saleh, was killed.

Air strikes hit a farm in the Ihsim region of Idlib where people who had been forced to flee their homes were taking shelter. The White Helmets rushed to the scene and were searching for survivors when the next strike hit the rescue effort killing Issam. The attack followed a pattern known as the "double tap" — where warplanes bomb an area, then bomb again, often after rescuers have arrived. Issam is the second White Helmet this week to be killed in these "double tap" Russian strikes. 

Issam leaves behind a two year old son and wife. Please donate what you can to the White Helmets Hero Fund so they and the other families left behind can be cared for.

https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBIssam

status_message: Syrians want to live in peace. At home. Urge European leaders to stop the bombs: https://act.thesyriacampaign.org/sign/we-want-to-go-home

Last Tuesday, Syrian rebels shelled government-held neighbourhoods in the northern city of Aleppo, killing 38 civilians– one of the highest death tolls cause by rebel shelling, according to
Syrian Network for Human Rights - الشبكة السورية لحقوق الإنسان, who reported more than 150 were injured. 

Rebel groups should be strongly condemned for these indiscriminate attacks, especially since it's not the first time that they have killed civilians in government-held areas. As the opposition, they can't claim moral high ground if their behaviour mirrors that of the regime.

Commenting on this attack Haid N. Haid, a Syrian activist at Planet Syria - كوكب سوريا wrote:

"Indiscriminate shelling by all sides should stop, especially by opposition groups which are supposed to be trying to create a more moral and humane alternative to the current regime. Most casualties of this shelling are civilians so we should condemn it just as strongly as we condemn indiscriminate attacks by the regime, while still acknowledging the differences between both sides. Our values, rather than the values of our enemies, should determine our behavior."

Join Planet Syria's call for an end to the violence: www.planetsyria.org

"Ich schreibe aus einer Flüchtlingsunterkunft in Deutschland. Alle Syrer hier sind so dankbar für die freundliche Aufnahme, die wir hier erleben. Doch wir wollen in Syrien leben, nicht in Deutschland.

Wir können nicht zurück gehen, wenn der Krieg nicht aufhört. Deswegen flehen wir Sie an, alles Ihnen mögliche zu tun, um diesen Krieg zu beenden. Alle Ihre Regierungen sind sich einig, dass ein politischer Wandel in Syrien notwendig ist, doch bis jetzt ist es bloß bei Worten geblieben. Assads Regierung ist noch immer an der Macht und tötet sieben Mal mehr Zivilisten als der IS.

Die Weltpolitiker müssen agieren, um die Bombardierungen zu stoppen. Wir können Scharfschützen und chemische Waffen überleben, aber die Fassbomben sind unerträglich. Eine Flugverbotszone oder eine Friedenszone würde auf der Stelle Leben retten. Und ich wäre die erste Person im Flieger zurück nach Hause.

Momentan sind wir in Europa Gesprächsthema Nummer Eins. Aber nicht viele hören uns zu. Bitte signieren Sie diese Petition, um Druck auf die europäischen Regierungsmächte auszuüben, damit sie mehr tun, um die Bomben zu stoppen und uns die gefahrlose Rückkehr in unsere Heimat zu ermöglichen.

http://act.thesyriacampaign.org/sign/we-want-to-go-home_de/"

Abo Adnan.

"Estou a escrever exte texto a partir de um campo de refugiados na Alemanha. Todos o Sírios que aqui se encontram estão muito gratos pela forma como foram recebidos, mas nós queremos viver na Síria, não na Alemanha.

Não podemos voltar enquanto que a guerra continue e esta é a razão pela qual vos pedimos que façam todos os possíveis para parar a guerra. Todos os vossos governos concordam que existe a necessidade de mudar a política da Síria, mas só palavras não são suficientes para que isto aconteça. O regime de Assad continua no poder, matando 7 vezes mais civis que o Estado Islâmico.

Os líderes mundiais têm de agir para cessar as bombas que caem dos céus. Nós podemos sobreviver aos atiradores, às armas químicas, mas as bombas barril são insuportáveis. A criação de uma zona com espaço aéreo fechado, uma zona segura, salvaria vidas instantaneamente. Eu seria a primeira pessoa no avião de volta para a Síria.

Neste momento, toda a gente na Europa fala de nós, refugiados. Mas ninguém nos ouve. Por favor, assinem esta petição dirigida aos lídes Europeus, pedindo que façam mais para parar as bombas para que possamos voltar a casa. 

http://act.thesyriacampaign.org/sign/we-want-to-go-home_pt/"

Abo Adnan

"Ik schrijf dit vanuit een vluchtelingenkamp in Duitsland. Alle Syriërs hier zijn zo dankbaar voor het welkom dat mensen ons hebben gegeven, maar we willen in Syrië en niet in Duitsland wonen.

Zolang de oorlog woedt kunnen wij niet terug en daarom vragen wij u om alles te doen om de oorlog te doen stoppen. Al uw regeringen zijn het eens dat er in Syrië een politieke overgang moet plaatsvinden maar alle woorden zijn onvoldoende om dit te bewerkstelligen. Het Assad regime heeft nog steeds de macht, en veroorzaakt de dood van zeven keer zoveel burgers als ISIS.

Wereldleiders moeten optreden om de de lucht bombardementen tegen te houden. We kunnen sluipschutters en chemicaliën overleven, maar de vatbommen zijn ondraaglijk. Een no-fly zone of een aantal veiligheidszones zouden direct mensenlevens redden. En ik zou op het eerste vliegtuig naar huis zitten.

Op dit moment spreekt iedereen in Europa over ons, vluchtelingen. Maar weinig mensen luisteren naar ons. Tekent u alstublieft deze petitie om de leiders van Europa te vragen om meer te doen om de bombardementen tegen te houden en ons te helpen om naar huis terug te keren.

https://act.thesyriacampaign.org/sign/we-want-to-go-home_NL?source=tta"

Abo Adnan

"Je vous écris ceci depuis un camp de réfugiés en Allemagne. Tous les Syriens sont reconnaissants pour l'accueil réservé par les gens d'ici mais nous voulons vivre en Syrie, pas en Allemagne.

Nous ne pouvons pas y retourner tant que la guerre continue. C'est pourquoi nous vous demandons de faire tout ce qui est en votre pouvoir pour arrêter la guerre. Tous vos gouvernements sont d'accord pour dire qu'il faut une transition politique en Syrie mais les paroles n'y font rien. Le régime d'Assad est toujours au pouvoir, tuant sept fois plus de civils qu' Isis.

Les dirigeants du monde doivent agir pour arrêter les bombes-barils. On peut survivre aux tirs de snipers, aux produits chimiques mais pas aux bombes-barils. Une zone d'interdiction de vol ou la création de zones de sécurité pourraient sauver des vies instantanément. Et je serais la première personne dans l'avion qui me ramènerait chez moi.

En ce moment, tout le monde en Europe parle des réfugiés syriens. Mais peu nous écoutent. Je vous demande de signer cette pétition adressée aux dirigeants européens leur demandant de faire plus pour arrêter les bombes et nous aider à rentrer chez nous.

http://act.thesyriacampaign.org/sign/we-want-to-go-home_fr/"

لا يمكننا العودة طالما الحرب مستعرة، لذلك نطلب منكم أن تفعلوا كل ما يمكنكم لوقف الحرب. كل حكوماتكم وافقت على أن الحل هو عبر انتقال سياسي في سوريا، لكن الكلام لن يكون كافيا لفعل أي شيء. نظام الأسد مازال في السلطة، يقتل من المدنيين 7 أضعاف ما يقتله تنظيم داعش الإلرهابي.

يجب على قادة العالم أن يتحركوا بوقف القنابل القادمة من السماء، تمكنا من النجاة من رصاص القناصة والأسلحة الكيميائية، إلا أن البراميل المتفجرة لا تحتمل. منظقة حظر طيران أو خلق منطقة آمنة ستوقف القتل فورا وسأكون أول شخص على الطائرة العائدة للوطن.

حاليا يتكلم الجميع عنّا نحن اللاجئين، ولكن قليلين فقط هم من يستمعون لنا. نطلب منكم أن توقعوا على هذه العريضة الموجهة للقادة الأوروبيين لنطلب منهم فعل المزيد لوقف القنابل ومساعدتنا على العودة للوطن."

SIGN: "My name is Abo Adnan and I'm a 27-year-old assistant surgeon from Syria. I arrived in Germany two weeks ago.

I had to cross twenty checkpoints on fake documents to make it out of Syria. Each time you know that there is a chance you will be arrested and taken away. Like so many others you fear the next your family will see of you is in torture pictures or, perhaps worse, never hear of you again.

The area I've been working in is called Ghouta. It was gassed with sarin by the regime of Bashar al-Assad in 2013 and the world did nothing. All of us responded to the attack that day and all of us suffered symptoms of chemical poisoning. But we carried on working.

Since then Ghouta has been under siege by the government, nothing is allowed in including medicines, and every day bombs rain from the skies. We have six field hospitals in Ghouta - one of them has an emergency room, one a surgery, one does blood analysis, another blood dialysis. All of them are underground to protect from bombing, but we have to transport patients between them overground. We have no ambulances under siege so we use a van with a bed in the back.

Medical workers have been systematically targeted by the Syrian regime and I have lost many friends and colleagues. They are killed because they are saving lives.

I am in Germany now because I need to finish my studies. I want to be a qualified surgeon so I can go back and help my people. Everyone here in this camp in Germany wants to go back. We appreciate the welcome and support of so many here in Europe but Syria is our home.

We cannot go back while the war continues which is why we are asking for you to do everything you can to stop the crisis. All major powers have agreed there needs to be a political transition in Syria but nothing has changed and the Assad regime is still in power, killing seven times more civilians than Isis.

A no-fly zone or safe zones to protect our hospitals and homes from aerial attacks is a critical first step. It will stop the biggest killer of civilians today and will also demonstrate that the world is serious about stopping the violence in Syria.

Stop the bombs so we can go home."

When barrel bombs are falling every day, there isn't much of a choice...
