Out of the mouth of children, comes truth...
A 13-year-old refugee puts in plain terms what needs to happen to end the 'refugee crisis'.
What would make thousands of families get on rubber boats headed to Europe? This. Watch and share.

Lots of people have contacted us this week asking about the best way to support Syrian refugees. We believe that these refugees are the best people to answer that question and we are working on a campaign to elevate their demands. Ahead of that we wanted to share some thoughts based on our experiences. In Syria, we have heard it time and time again, and unequivocally. To end the conflict, to defeat Isis, and to return to their homes, Syrians are calling for a no-fly zone.

Since the picture of Aylan hit headlines across the world 6 children have been killed in Syria every day, the majority from barrel bombs and missiles from Syrian government aircraft. But their bloodied and blown apart corpses don't make the front page of any newspaper. None of the other 10,000 children killed in the fighting have.

The war in Syria has killed more than 300,000 people and displaced 12 million, forcing more than four million to flee the country -- the UN has called it "the greatest humanitarian crisis of our era." But what happening in Syria is also a crisis of politics and humanity. Syria is not an earthquake or a natural disaster; these crimes have agents and perpetrators, none of which is greater than the Syrian government, which is responsible for over 85% of civilian deaths.

Since 2012 the Syrian Government has waged an aerial war on Syrian civilians as a form of collective punishment for daring to ask for the freedom and democracy that people in Europe and America enjoy. As the UN has said, most of the killing of civilians today comes from the regime's "indiscriminate aerial weapons", the leading one is the barrel bomb.They kill civilians and shatter communities who want no part in the violence. The fear of these bombs drives mass displacement -- 500,000 people fled Aleppo as a result of the aerial campaign in four months alone. Aylan's family fled Aleppo due to the aerial attacks. 

Every barrel bomb dropped deepens the cycle of violence and extremism. Left unchecked these barrel bombs will continue to strengthen ISIS, continue to attract more foreign fighters to Syria and that crisis too will explode onto mainland Europe with more terror attacks.  

In February 2014, the UN Security Council [in a rare moment of consensus] banned the use of barrel bombs but since then the attacks have only increased. The Syrian government has repeatedly ignored UN resolutions, and the strong words and hand wringing from the international community has done nothing to stop the killing. 

The international community can end these attacks. A Bosnia style no-fly zone could be put in place to stop the Syrian government's airforce from bombing its own people. A no-fly zone does not need to be a major military undertaking. The 67+ country US-led anti-Isis coalition is already flying in areas where the barrel bombs are being dropped.

Syrians don't want to be resettled in distant lands or rely on ever-dwindling aid packages. They want what everyone wants – to live in their own homes in safety and with dignity. A no-fly zone would stop more people fleeing, allow millions to return home and help civil society flourish. Furthermore it would help create the conditions for real, internationally-backed talks.

The answer is clear for how best to support Syrian refugees. We must all call on our governments to support a no-fly zone.
Read and share a longer version of this post here: https://diary.thesyriacampaign.org/ending-the-refugee-crisis-starts-with-ending-the-syria-crisis/

Sharing an important post from Kenan Rahmani, a Syrian American activist.

"The ultimate injustice one can commit to Aylan Kurdi and his family is to omit the parts of his story which explain why he ended up dead on the beach. The details matter, so please read and share:

1) Abdullah Kurdi, the father, was detained for 5 months in Air Force Intelligence in Damascus. While in detention, he was tortured and his teeth were pulled out. He had to sell his shop in Damascus in order to bribe the officers to let him out. This cost him 5,000,000 Syrian Liras (around $25,000)

2) After he bribed his way out of jail, Abdullah fled to Aleppo with his wife and sons, Aylan and Ghalib. The situation in Aleppo became dangerous due to the constant aerial bombardment, so he fled again to Kobani, his hometown.

3) When ISIS attacked Kobani last year, the family could no longer live in their hometown, so they fled to Turkey. Once in Turkey, the Turkish government did not provide them with assistance, so they paid almost $6,000 to secure 4 spots on a rubber dingy to the Greek island of Kos. 

4) While on the boat, rough waters caused the boat to flip. The lifejackets they were given were fake. His sons and wife all drowned in front of his eyes, in his arms.

5) Abdullah Kurdi and his brother wanted to seek refuge in Canada, where their sister lives. However his brother's application was rejected, so then the families decided to pay a smuggler to take them to Greece by boat. After Aylan's photo became a media story, he was reportedly offered citizenship to Canada. But now he doesn't want to go to Canada or Europe anymore. He says he will go bury his family in Kobani and stay there to fight against ISIS, because everything has been taken away from him and he has "nothing to live for."

So if the world wants to see no more Aylans on the beach, someone needs to do some combination of the following based on above: (1) stop torture and arbitrary detention by the Assad regime, (2) stop the regime's aerial bombardment, (3) stop ISIS, (4) make traveling to Europe safe, (5) get Canada and the USA to accept more refugees."

"You have to understand that no one puts their child in a boat unless the water is safer than the land." 

Artwork by Tammam Azzam 

Aylan Kurdi drowned alongside his 5 year old brother Galip, and mother, Rehan. The whole of his short life was lived under war. 

If we do not stop the violence against civilians in Syria, families will continue to risk their lives simply to live. 

Ending the 'refugee crisis' starts with ending the fighting in Syria.

"My name is Mohamed and I'm from Dera'a, Syria. My family, friends and neighbours know me as 'Abul Ward,' Arabic for 'father of the roses.' I got this name since I was known for my garden filled with flowers, and because I loved to give everyone a flower that passed by my house.

In early 2011, I had been a fire fighter for the Syrian government for 13 years. When my neighbours' kids were caught, tortured, and thrown into a prison for writing 'anti-government' slogans on the walls of their school, I defected. How could I stand to support a system that supports torturing innocent children? I was the first to leave my team, but soon after, most of my squad defected behind me.

A couple weeks after I defected I was stopped at a checkpoint by the regime. They took me to a state prison for two months. My experiences of torture in a sweltering pitch-black confined room with over 100 people are memories that will scar my past but empower my future. For every moldy piece of bread I was forced to eat, for every kick and punch I got, and for my fellow inmates who didn't make it out alive, I am living my life more fully for it.

From the time I was hung by hands for four days straight, to when my heart stopped for three minutes before I was revived, all the suffering I experienced made me stronger and more resilient. Now I am a White Helmet volunteer. After I left prison, I heard about these men and women who were rescuing people from under the rubble, and were also fighting fire. I knew this was the place for me.

For the past year we have been saving lives and pulling people from under the destruction of their homes and buildings, but we can't save everyone. Destruction, pain and heartbreak can last for a lifetime, but beautiful things may appear in the wake of tragedy. Once, we buried a few young men killed by barrel bombs. We buried the men a day after their murder; when our team and family returned to the gravesite a few weeks later, we were surprised to find no foul stench and the most beautiful flowers growing there. 

When I think about the Syrian struggle, I can't help but think of my favourite flower, the orchid. The orchid is a symbol of the Syrian people, for regardless of what season it is, the flower is able to survive. This flower demonstrates strength, resilience and beauty, just like those Syrians who are still struggling for freedom peacefully despite all the obstacles.

My dream for my beloved Syria is for it not to be covered with barrel bombs, destruction, war and blood, but with flowers, from my city of Dera'a all the way to the north of Syria and the border of Turkey. Every flower will represent our brothers and sisters for their strength, resilience and beautiful memories for reaching a better tomorrow."

Two years ago, the Syrian regime used the chemical agent sarin to gas hundreds of civilians in Ghouta. Entire families foamed at the mouth after the dawn attack, shaking in shock, and hundreds died. Little bodies were lined up in rows, the lack of blood making it appear as if they were asleep.

The pictures from Ghouta shocked and angered people all over the world. Bashar al-Assad had joined the only two leaders in 90 years to have used chemical weapons against their own people: Saddam Hussein and Adolf Hitler. Barack Obama said a red line had been crossed and a threat of force by the US led Assad to agree to destroy his chemical stockpiles.

Fast forward two years later to today, and Syrians are still being gassed. Barrel bombs are being filled with chlorine and dropped onto family homes, turning them into gas chambers. Yet it's not the chemicals killing most Syrians - it's the bombs themselves. There were nearly 7,000 airstrikes by the Syrian regime in July alone.

To break the silence and spread the truth we are asking people around the world to join or organise a #ClearTheSky action on the anniversary of the Ghouta chemical weapon  attack. Look up in solidarity with us.

status_message:
5 things everyone should know about what is happening in Syria today.

1 - The Syrian regime of Bashar al-Assad is killing at least 7 times more civilians than Isis.

2 - More than 11,000 barrel bombs made of scrap metal and high explosives have been rolled out of regime helicopters onto hospitals, homes and schools since the UN banned them. These aerial attacks are the biggest killer of civilians. They drive extremism.

3 - These barrel bombs are a leading cause of displacement, forcing refugees to cross the Mediterranean and other borders.

4 - Many of the barrel bombs are dropped on areas under siege. More than half a million people in Syria live in areas with no access to food, water or medicine since 2013, including the areas of Ghouta that were targeted by the sarin gas attacks in the same year.

5 - The international anti-Isis coalition is flying in the same airspace where many of these barrel bombs are dropped, choosing to look the other way

There is no military solution to the fighting in Syria. But like in Bosnia, a no-fly zone can help protect civilians from the worst of the violence and encourage the fighting parties to come to the negotiating table.

Too many Syrians spend their days looking up at the sky, wondering when the next barrel bomb will drop and what it will hit. Today we are looking up in solidarity with all those who continue on and join the call to #clearthesky. 

https://www.facebook.com/events/1615390465405371/

Join hundreds of non-violent Syrian groups in asking for the international community to enforce the UN ban on barrel bombs with a Bosnia-style no-fly zone.

Just a heads up: This is a happy story. 

On Sunday, the suburb of Douma was heavily targeted with missiles by the regime, massacring over 100 civilians and injuring hundreds more. It was a glimpse of the brutality the regime is inflicting on everyday civilians. But its brutality is no match for the resilience of its people…

Mohammed Rayhan never returned home after the attacks on Sunday. Three days had passed since and his family was certain he was dead. They held a funeral wake in their home and began to mourn the loss of Rayhan. As they were grieving, Rayhan walked in on them. Covered in dust and debris, he showed up to his own funeral!

It turns out Rayhan had been trapped beneath the rubble without food or water for three straight days. But he clung on to life. The White Helmets were conducting search and rescue operations for missing people and were able to find and extract him.

His family's tears of sadness turned to tears of joy as what was a funeral now became a celebration for his return from the rubble.

A barrel bomb an hour. For 24 hours.

Recorded from 18:00 hours on 18th August to 18:00 hours on 19th August by Syrian Network for Human Rights - الشبكة السورية لحقوق الإنسان

That's 42 too many.

From a doctor in Douma:

When I arrived at the Intensive Care Unit, minutes after the air raid, a man stopped me and said "don't go in there because there's no space left in the ICU except for the wounded" then another man interrupted him "let him in, he's a doctor."

I wish I had not been in that hospital yesterday and that I did not see what I saw -- a sea of blood and the wounded, doctors and medics were swimming in it.

I moved through rows of injured people, all lying on the ground in a critical condition, and each tried to muster some strength to motion to me with their hands or to whimper, anything that expresses their pain. They wanted to send me the message ' I am wounded and you have been chosen by God to rescue me or else to experience pain from your inability to rescue me.'

As I come to the realization that we have all reached breaking point in that wretched hospital room, a voice came down to us as if from above. We all listen attentively to this voice hoping it will say something to calm us down, the voice starts... "Guys, empty the Intensive Care Unit.. the warplane has launched a second strike, and a third, and... and a tenth."

And I begin to see the injuries multiplying, the number of deaths multiplying. And I realize there is no more blood for transfusions, no more sanitized medical equipment and no more serum bags but we continue working as if it's the end of the world.

Even the wounded look at you with the eyes of those who have been condemned to hope, and as soon as you're done with an injured civilian, another looks at you with pleading eyes that are saying "my fate depends on you." As I'm heading towards one of the victims, another one lying prostrate on the ground right next to him takes hold of my arm and pleads: "Doctor I swear I was here before him. I arrived right after the first strike." And in that moment, I wish I could be shattered into hundreds of pieces so that each piece could treat someone's brother or mother or father.  

Then my colleague, another doctor helping treat the wounded, yells: "come check out my cousin. I think he died but I can't make a final decision."

Another one yells: "Doctor, come see this guy that I tried to revive. I think he's dead."

Other people stand around and ask: "that guy breathing from his neck, is there anything we can do to help him?"

"Doctor, is there anything I can help you with?" I turn around and see an ophthalmologist who came from Ghouta to share my burden and carry out the duty that God has thrust upon him. Same with the pediatrician and same with the neurologist. Because they see all the wounded as family. Syrians are one people.

A few hours have elapsed since the air raid and I now look across the Intensive Care Unit. At least the ground has been emptied of its injured although the beds are still all occupied. I begin to feel that the situation is a bit more manageable now. This is when the rescue operations end and the real catastrophe begins. The Syria Civil Defense teams have documented more than 100 deaths.

100 souls that have left this life

100 families who have lost a member

100 women who have lost a son, a husband or a brother

100 men who have lost a son, a daughter, a husband, a father or a sibling

I move through the operation rooms and see exhausted doctors who have performed more than 70 surgeries during the past few hours. They have seen guts spilled out, amputated legs, dislodged eyes, slashed necks --- their green scrubs are dark from the blood.

As for those who have made it through the chaotic ICU and surgery, they are looking at days or weeks at the hospital while they recover.

For me I want the world to act to stop the killing. I don't know how else to say it.

On Sunday the Assad regime dropped missiles targeting ordinary civilians as they shopped in the market for fruit and vegetables.  

The White Helmets rushed to save who they could. For others all they could do was dig their graves. Donate to support these heroes. https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund

122 barrel bombs in 4 days. More than 100 civilians massacred in Douma yesterday alone. Share if you agree it's time for a No-Fly Zone in Syria.

Syrian Network for Human Rights - الشبكة السورية لحقوق الإنسان

Yesterday, the Syrian regime launched air raids on the main market in the Douma suburb of Damascus during rush hour. Over 100 civilians have died and hundreds of others were wounded. 

The target for the first missile was a crowded market square filled with everyday people buying fruits and vegetables. The second missile targeted rescue workers and medics at the scene. The area has been under siege so there wasn't the medical supplies or trained staff needed to cope with such injuries. So many were killed the White Helmets had to dig mass graves to bury the martyrs.

Yet this attack did not make the TV news, it was a small article in some papers, others ignored it altogether.

A No Fly Zone over Syria would have saved the lives of over 100 people in Douma yesterday. How many more Syrians will be killed before they are granted the universal right of protection? 

The time to act is now. Support the Syrian people's right to live and protect their children. Support a No Fly Zone for Syria: https://www.whitehelmets.org/?source=FBDoumamrkt

"Three months ago, my beloved 5-year-old son, Yazan, was killed in our home by a barrel bomb. He died in my arms.

That day, I vowed I would never leave Syria. I couldn't save my own son's life, but maybe I could save the lives of other people.

I am a member of the Civil Defense Force in Syria. 

When the helicopter approached my house and started to hover over it, all the neighbors were screaming. My wife grabbed our infant son, Zain, and I picked up Yazan, but we couldn't reach our shelter in time.

One minute, I was holding Yazan in my arms, and the next minute, the bomb exploded.

He was gone.

The pressure of the bomb had catapulted him out of the house, and we found him outside, covered in rubble, dead.

My White Helmet colleagues came to rescue us. They brought him to the hospital, but I knew he was dead because of what he'd said to me just before the bomb hit.

He told me, "Papa, I am going to be martyred, and I am going to take all of you with me." Then, he died.

The White Helmets rescued my wife, Asma'a, and Zain out of the rubble.

Yazan was such a clever boy. He never forgot a single thing I told him. He used to say, "When I get older, Papa, I will be a civil defender, just like you." He had just started learning the alphabet in kindergarten.

To lose my son was God's will, but it has paralyzed my thoughts. I cannot think too much about it. I guess I am still in shock.

But, ever since it happened, I carry on working. It helps me to do something useful every day. I always tell myself, "I am not the first person to lose my son, and I will not be the last."

Our house was close to a military airbase, so it was vulnerable to attack. We civil defense forces are often attacked, and our base has been bombed six times.

Ninety-three White Helmets have died in Syria since we started rescuing people. Most of them were young men with wives and children. I am 32.

We are now living in a temporary space our neighbors found for us while we look for a new home. It is cramped, and we all share one room.

My family has enough to get by for now. We're lucky to have some land, and we grow vegetables.

Not all are as lucky as us. Very little aid comes through this town. A few charities give small amounts to the poorest people or to prisoners, but most people get by with nothing.

Before the revolution, I worked dyeing wool in a government-run weaving factory. I will not return to that job.

I will never leave Syria.

It is my responsibility as a civil defender to stay and help my people. But, we are running out of hope that this destruction will ever end.

The head of the White Helmets went to the UN Security Council and gave all the facts – the bombs that were attacking us, the chlorine attacks — but with all the talk in the international community, we've seen nothing change.

My dream is that people can return to their homes without fear. We don't want to hear any more jet fighters or military aircrafts hovering over our houses.

And my biggest hope for my son, Zain, is that he can grow up in peace, go to college and make something of his life."

AMAR. SHARE HIS STORY.

Hussam one of the White Helmets at Tuesday night's scene of an alleged US air strike which killed eight civilians in Atmeh including five young sisters.

Syria needs less bombs, not more. Call on the US and other world powers to use their intervention to stop the bombs, not add to them. Join the White Helmets call for a no-fly zone now www.whitehelmets.org?source=fbhsmat

"I am a member of the Civil Defense Force in Syria. We are called the White Helmets.

In the absence of ambulance or fire services, we have taken on the role of trying to rescue people from the rubble after a bomb has been detonated. Most of them are ordinary people who have been killed in their own homes.

I joined the White Helmets five months ago, and I've saved about 20 people since then.

When I'm pulling people out of the rubble, it feels like I've just given birth or have helped someone give birth to a new child.

It makes me very happy to know I am helping my fellow Syrians through this ugly war, but at the same time, I feel deep sadness after seeing people going through so much pain.

I live in the town of Khan Sheikhoun, which is in the Governorate of Idlib. Every day, the government rains down bombs on Khan Sheikhoun.

At least two barrel bombs are dropped each day, and now, a terrifying new type of bomb is being used. We call them navy mines. They contain the same explosives as barrel bombs, but they explode in the air instead of on the ground.

They make a horrifying noise when they explode. It is like an earthquake, and for a few minutes, it feels as if the whole town has been demolished, and everybody has died.

They are designed to make us panic and to terrorize us. It works.

We blast sirens as soon as we hear a plane or a helicopter approaching with the intent to bomb, but we usually don't have enough time to warn people to flee."

AMAR. 32 YEARS OLD. HERO. SHARE HIS STORY.

"Regime forces have built an artificial berm of earth approximately four metres high blocking the only remaining route into or out of the town of Moadamiyeh in Damascus, which has already been under a crippling siege and regular bombardment by Assad's forces for over three years.

44,000 trapped civilians fearful of massacres. Assad's forces bomb town for three consecutive nights, killing and injuring dozens.

Despite announcing a truce in 2014, the regime has continued to deny access to food, medicine and humanitarian aid to these remaining townspeople.

Pleas from medics in the town's remaining field hospital (which has barely any medicine or equipment due to the regime siege) to allow the evacuation of the worst injured for medical treatment have been ignored, with international humanitarian organisations not responding to SOS messages."

-Dani Qappani, an activist living under siege in Moadamiyeh

Mazen Darwish is a prominent Syrian human rights lawyer and free speech advocate. He was arrested, along with 16 of his colleagues, on February 16th, 2012 during a raid carried out by the intelligence services on the Syrian Center for Media and Freedom of Expression (SCM) which Darwish founded. As soon as Darwish was detained, he was denied access to a lawyer, his family members were not allowed to talk to him and, despite news that he had been brutally tortured, he was not given any medical care.

For a while nothing was known about Mazen's fate. His wife was able to glean some details about where he was being held and how he was being treated from former detainees who had chanced upon him in the Mezzeh Air force detention center, one of the most feared prisons in Syria.

It should be noted that Mazen was no stranger to persecution. In the years leading up to his arrest, he had experienced constant harassment at the hands of security services due to his great work in human rights. Not only was he prohibited from practicing law for life, he was also banned from traveling for four years and had to report to security forces on an almost daily basis.

Despite these considerable difficulties, Mazen Darwish was determined to stay in Syria because he adamantly believed in the ability of human rights activists to triumph against all odds if they carried on their work for dignity and justice in a country lacking both. When the uprising erupted in Syria in 2011, the Syrian government began rounding up all prominent human rights defenders who had been speaking out against human rights violations. Mazen Darwish was sadly one of them. His friends' warnings fell on deaf ears and he chose to remain in Syria because everything he had always hoped for was finally materializing. The fight for justice had arrived to Syria. He often told his wife that it was was his duty to continue, unrelentingly, to report on the human rights abuses that were taking place every day- rampant crimes against humanity, summary executions and savage torture in Syria's hidden detention centers.

Mazen's story is one amongst many. There is a multitude of brave activists currently languishing in prison, countless enforced disappearances and families torn apart by loss after loss. These people are seized from their homes or work places just for speaking out against the government and many of them await military trials for nonexistent crimes.

Mazen was released today after more than three years in prison, ahead of a final verdict in his case on August 21. He will still be tried despite not having committed any crime except speak out against the state's repression and human rights violations.

"The parallel example for Syria is not Iraq, Afghanistan or Libya – it's Bosnia. 

Like the Syrian conflict today, Bosnia saw horrific atrocities, unprecedented numbers of refugees and an exorbitant death toll. Terms like "genocide" and "ethnic cleansing" became familiar, just as "barrel bombs" and "chlorine gas" are becoming familiar today. 

In both Syria and Bosnia, we saw state and non-state actors unafraid of using violence against civilians. And we saw calculating elites eager to exploit ethnic and religious differences and foment religious extremism on all sides...The intervention in Bosnia saved lives. It dampened extremism. And it ultimately brought the conflict to an end. Intervention – in the form of a no-fly zone – could offer similar benefits in Syria by stopping what is now the leading killer of Syrian civilians: Assad's barrel bombs." 
-Former Bosnian ambassador to the United Nations. 

Join the call for a no-fly zone now: www.whitehelmets.org?source=Bosnia

Let's hit the goal for these heroes:https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBfatality

This past Valentine's Day, Loay, a White Helmet, brought his love a token of affection between the moments of chaos. Three hours later he was injured in a blast.

The risk that the White Helmets put themselves in for others is nothing short of inspiring. Loay is fine now - and the White Helmets have set up a fund for all other injured rescue workers. 

Show your love here, every dollar makes a difference: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBLoay

On June 26, in the village of Balyoon in Idlib, aircrafts targeted the civil defence centre, the neighbourhood mosque and a few civilian homes. 20 shells were dropped from helicopters, killing 1 man and injuring 30, among them 6 White Helmets.

That was one day's destruction. But this happens every day in Syria. Show your support for wounded rescue workers by helping pay their medical bills here: herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBidlib

A message from Raed, Head of the White Helmets:
"Thank you for your donation to our injured teammates. I've been following the campaign's progress closely and, honestly, I'm overwhelmed with happiness.

I recently addressed the UN Security Council as head of the Syria Civil Defence about what they would do to stop the bombs in Syria. When I asked them what am I supposed to tell my colleagues upon my return, none of the leaders gave me an answer. Most Syrians had warned me before I left to testify, insisting that the world no longer cares about us, that we've become just a series of numbers for them. But two days after the launch of this campaign, I gained new clarity. It's become very clear to me that humanity does not differentiate based on ethnicity or race or colour. You have given a glimmer of hope to all the heroes who work tirelessly to help people on a daily basis.

I want to thank you from the bottom of my heart for giving hope to the heroes of the civil defence, for enabling them to carry on with their daily work and sacrifices in their quest to save humanity."

The Hero Fund is being powered by small donations from people around the world: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBRaed

In the photo below, White Helmet volunteers are sitting down to break their Ramadan fast while looking up at the sky in anticipation of incoming barrel bombs. 

They've been saving lives throughout these long summer days, fasting through their rescue missions as the bombs fall relentlessly. So on Eid, the day which marks the end of the holy month of Ramadan, let's help get them the BEST. PRESENT. EVER.

Eid is tomorrow, and we're 90% of the way toward meeting our goal. Let's meet the target and make this Eid amazing. 

Chip in what you can: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBramadan

status_message:
We just received this story in a WhatsApp message from our White Helmet contacts:

Fares Muhammad Ali (right), a young volunteer rescue worker with The White Helmets, was wounded while he was rescuing people who had been injured by aerial bombardment in the town of Hreitan today.

Fares and his colleagues headed straight to the area after the shelling. As soon as they got there, warplanes launched another attack on the same site. Fares sustained serious wounds, one of the tendons in his hand was severed and his head is injured as well.

Fares joined The White Helmets' Hreitan division in May 2013 and was promoted shortly after to Head of the Firefighters.

Fares is just one of these heroes sacrificing everything for the safety of their people. Donate to help with the medical treatment of injured White Helmets: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBFares

"At the risk of seeming ridiculous, let me say that the true revolutionary is guided by a great feeling of love. It is impossible to think of a genuine revolutionary lacking this quality... We must strive every day so that this love of living humanity will be transformed into actual deeds, into acts that serve as examples, as a moving force."

- Che Guevara

status_message:
On May 14th, a barrel bomb was dropped in Khan Sheikhoun. While the helicopter was still in the sky, team members were evacuating residents to a neighbourhood shelter. But they didn't finish in time...

At the moment of the explosion, Bashar was at the entrance to the shelter. Bits of shrapnel entered his head, chest and hand. He was taken to a hospital outside the city for treatment.

Three days later, he was taken to Al Raha hospital where surgery was performed on his hand. A nerve was hit in the operation and he could no longer move it properly and lost sensation in his fingers. 

Ten days later he was taken to a hospital in Kafranbel. A specialist conducted another surgery to fix the nerve. Based on doctors' reports, his teammates are saying that the injury might cause permanent disability in his left hand and loss of sensation. 

You can donate to help Bashar and his teammates receive the medical treatment they need: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBBashar

The regime will keep taking life. We'll keep giving to those who give life.

Donate here: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBJuly10

In Syria, the heroes voluntarily saving people from crude barrel bombs are targeted. When they're hurt or they're taken from their families, there are no funds to treat or support them. That's why we've set up a Hero Fund.

Donate and invest in life: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBintensivecare

At dinner time on the 4th of July, the White Helmets were at their command centre in Al Ghab (NW Syria) when they heard the familiar sound of regime helicopters hover overhead. This is a sound Syrians now associate with death and terror, a sign that a barrel bomb is about to be dropped. As the volunteers got their kits ready to respond to the attack, the bomb was dropped meters from the centre.

Debris, explosives and shrapnel hit and damaged the center, as well as injuring one of the White Helmets, Obaid Al Ismael, a fire fighter, fracturing his right leg.

Donate to Obaid to show that though his government is against him, you see him as a hero: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBObaid

The regime won't let up. As it continues to drop bombs killing civilians, the volunteer first-responders of the White Helmets keep saving civilians. Let's be sure these heroes get the medical attention deserved when injured during their rescues.

Give today. 100% of your donation gets to them: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBJuly9

WE'RE NEAR $50,000!
The White Helmets mean life in the world's most dangerous place. The group of less than 2,700 volunteer first-responders have saved more than 21,000 Syrians who have found themselves under senseless attack.

Donate so they can keep saving lives: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBlivessaved

Abdulmalek was a firefighter before the revolution. In 2013, he became one of the founders of the White Helmets. After saving five lives in a single rescue he was hit by a mortar blast and lost his leg.

Unable to work as a White Helmet, Abdulmalek fell into depression. Worried about his health, his teammates scraped together the cash needed for a prosthetic leg. Now Abdulmalek is back behind the wheel of an ambulance in Idlib saving countless more innocent people.

Injured volunteers are going untreated and families unsupported because the money isn't there. That's exactly where people around the world can help. Together we can raise $100,000 to start a Hero Fund and make sure these brave volunteers and their families are looked after.

Donate. Every dollar makes a difference: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBAbdulmalek

In those 24 hours we raised $8,000 for the heroes responding to those bombings. Let's get them even more and ensure they receive medical treatment when injured in the line of duty.

Donate now: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBbarrelbombs

Muhannad is a husband, a father and a White Helmet. He recently lost a leg while on duty. 

"Before the revolution I worked in electronics. When the revolution began, I searched for a place for myself among the revolutionaries. I worked doing various things to express my demands for freedom for each person in Syria.

In 2014, I began working as a civil defender in order to help my family and my neighbours – and I fully believe that all Syrians are my family and neighbours. I was well aware that this work exposed me to serious injury and I was fine with that.

I lost a limb; my left leg. This is the least of my duties for my family in Jisr Al Shughour. I am determined to continue this work – even with one leg, I do whatever I can. What I fear is witnessing an attack where I won't be able to save a soul from under the rubble.

Even with my injury I will try my hardest to finish this journey with my teammates. They deserve respect and appreciation and I take my helmet off to them."

Donate to The White Helmets Hero Fund to get Muhannad a prosthetic leg: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBMuhannad

Everyday bombs fall in Syria. And everyday the White Helmets are there to rescue the injured. But what happens when the rescuers get injured? 

We've started a Hero Fund to treat injured White Helmets and provide for their families and the internet has helped us raise more than $35,000! But, we want to give these heroes $100,000. Keep giving: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBInvested

These volunteer first-responders have the biggest hearts. Saving life under bombardment. And because of that they're targeted by the regime.

Together we've raised more than $30,000 to create a Hero Fund to ensure these these selfless heroes get medical care when injured. But we're not at our goal yet. Keep giving: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBheart

In one day, we've raised more than $25,000 for the heroes of The White Helmets. Let's keep up the momentum and get from 25% to 30% of our goal. It'd take 100 people donating $50 to get there.

Can we raise that off this link? Let's see! We're tracking it so donate and share using this: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBChallenge

Murhaf Ismail Salat is 21. He was a student before he joined The White Helmets 2 years ago as a rescue worker and firefighter knowing it was a dangerous profession. Still, the work appealed to him because it was humanitarian and charitable. His biggest fear was being injured or killed while on duty. This past May, just that happened...

"I was on my way to Sarmeen with my brothers [colleagues] to put out a fire when a missile landed right on top of me and my team of firefighters. My friend died and I lost my leg. When the strike doesn't kill you, it returns you to life much stronger. I am proud of what happened to me and hopefully nothing can stop me from serving my country, neither a missing arm nor a missing leg.

When you establish such a fund for the families of the fallen, it shows us that you haven't forgotten us. It makes us feel that someone still cares."

Donate to the Hero Fund which will provide Murhaf and the White Helmet heroes with medical coverage for things like prosthetic limbs: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBMurhaf

In the few hours since we've launched the Hero Fund to cover medical expenses for The White Helmets, more than 200 people have raised 10% of the goal already! Amazing. But we've got more ground to cover. Please keep sharing and if you haven't given yet, do that here: https://herofund.whitehelmets.org/donate/crowdfund?source=FBupdate

BREAKING: we won! The European Parliament has decided to stop #hidingtorture and agreed to exhibit the "Caesar" photos showing the Assad's regime systematic torture.

Thanks to everyone who sent 5,000+ emails and piled on social media pressure to overturn the decision.

This is an example of what we can do for Syria when we work together to pressure decision makers. Politicians need to see the ongoing war crimes in Syria. If they don't see them, what hope is there they'll stop them?

The first of July has started off no differently... Today, more than two bombs every hour were dropped on civilians.  It's time for us to act. It's time for a no-fly zone: www.whitehelmets.org?source=FBjuly

"Even in the norms of war, there is no justification for the use of this weapon, because even the pilot himself, who's dropping the barrel bomb, does not know exactly where it will fall. It is a fully indiscriminate weapon and cannot be used on the front line because it might kill allied forces—which is why it is only dropped deep inside opposition-held areas.

The main purpose of this weapon is collective punishment for communities that have left Syrian Regime control, in order to make their lives Hell and convey a false message to Syrians that they cannot live except under the Assad family's governance."
-Raed, Head of The White Helmets at the UN
Read his brave speech in its entirety here: https://diary.thesyriacampaign.org/as-a-patriotic-syrian-i-never-imagined-i-would-do-this/

"The legitimacy of the international community lost its credibility for Syrians in the absence of the political will to end the killing in Syria, and the UN Security Council has transformed from the Security to the Insecurity Council in the eyes of the suffering people because it failed to uphold its own resolutions"
-Raed, Head of The White Helmets

Support Raed and his comrades here: www.whitehelmets.org?source=FBUnresolved

status_message:
يوم الجمعة قال رئيس الخوذات البيضاء رائد الصالح  الحقيقة أمام مجلس الأمن الدولي .

حضرات السادة
ماذا تتوقعون من سوري بسيط مثلي أن يطلب من هذا المجلس؟ هل نطلب مزيدا من سيارات الإسعاف التي سيدمرها النظام؟ هل نطلب مزيدا من معدات الحفر لسحب مزيد من الجثث والأشلاء ودفنها؟ أم هل نطلب قرارات إدانة جديدة تضاف إلى القرارات السابقة التي وقعتم أنتم عليها ولازال بعضكم يمد النظام بالدعم السياسي والمادي والعسكري بما في ذلك قطع الغيار لطائراته التي يستخدمها في رمي هذه البراميل وقتل مزيد من السوريين؟

لقد فقدت الشرعية الدولية مصداقيتها أمام السوريين في ظل غياب إرادة سياسية لوقف القتل في سوريا وتحول مجلس الأمن في أعين المعذبين إلى مجلس اللا أمن بسبب عجزه عن احترام قراراته
إن الشعب السوري الذي يقتل كل يوم يحملكم المسؤولية يا سادة ويطالب باتخاذ كل الإجراءات الكفيلة بوقف القتل فورا في سوريا وبخاصة الاسلحة العشوائية.

إنني كسوري وطني ماكنت لأتخيل نفسي يوما أطالب بتدخل أجنبي في بلادي لا برا ولا جوا، ولكن أرواح الأبرياء من النساء والأطفال الذين نراهم يموتون بين يدينا كل يوم تدفعنا إلى طلب أي تدخل ممكن لوقف آلة القتل الهمجية التي يقودها بشار الأسد بما في ذلك منع الطائرات السورية وخاصة الحوامات من التحليق وإلقاء حممها https://diary.thesyriacampaign.org/%D8%A5%D9%86%D9%86%D9%8A-%D9%83%D8%B3%D9%88%D8%B1%D9%8A-%D9%88%D8%B7%D9%86%D9%8A-%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%83%D9%86%D8%AA-%D9%84%D8%A3%D8%AA%D8%AE%D9%8A%D9%84-%D9%86%D9%81%D8%B3%D9%8A-%D9%8A%D9%88%D9%85%D8%A7/

To stop the barrel bombs, Syria needs a no-fly zone. To get a no-fly zone, Syria needs all of us. Can you get a friend to join The White Helmets call for an end to the bombs?

Sign here: www.whitehelmets.org

On Friday, Raed Saleh, Head of the White Helmets spoke truth to power as he called on the Council to take action to stop the barrel bombs.

"Ladies and Gentlemen, what do you expect a simple Syrian citizen like me to ask from this council? Do we ask for more ambulances that the Syrian Regime will soon destroy anyway? Do we ask for more digging tools to recover bodies and limbs and bury them? Or do we ask for new resolutions condemning these acts to be added to the previous list of resolutions that you've signed, while some of you are still supporting the Syrian Regime politically, materially and militarily, including with spare parts for the aircraft used to drop these barrel bombs and kill more Syrians?

The international community has lost its credibility for Syrians in the absence of any political will to end the killing in Syria, and the UN Security Council has been transformed from the Security to the Insecurity Council in the eyes of the downtrodden because it has failed to uphold its own resolutions.

As a patriotic Syrian, I never imagined I would one day ask for a foreign intervention in my country, by land or air. But the lives of innocent women and children that we see dying in our hands every day compel us to ask for any intervention possible to stop the barbaric killing machine led by Bashar al-Assad, including preventing Syrian aircraft from flying, and especially preventing helicopters from hovering above us and dropping these bombs."

Read the full speech here: https://diary.thesyriacampaign.org/as-a-patriotic-syrian-i-never-imagined-i-would-do-this/

We've heard from an EU Parliament representative that they're trying to find a solution to officially holding a photo exhibit of Syria's torture victims.

Until they do, let's keep up the pressure: https://act.thesyriacampaign.org/letter/europe-stop-hiding-crimes?source=FBHussein

"Can you imagine how we live even for one day?" The White Helmets testified at a UN hearing today, asking for a no-fly zone and an end to the bombs.

If you support them please add your name here: www.whitehelmets.org

The regime won't let up. But neither will we. Keep spreading these images so others know how crucial it is that Syria sees a no-fly zone to stop the barrel bombs.

Sign here: www.whitehelmets.org
21 more than yesterday. Share this image and tag your friends, unless we mobilise everyone we know to support a no-fly zone, more days will pass with more bombs killing civilians.

The European Parliament is choosing not to show photos exposing the brutal torture that's being carried out in Syria. They say it's too "offensive and disturbing". But it's the reality of what's happening and hiding these photos won't make that reality disappear. 

Let's put some pressure on Parliament to officially open the exhibition and expose Assad's heinous acts: https://act.thesyriacampaign.org/letter/europe-stop-hiding-crimes?source=FBSamanthaQuote
41 barrel bombs were dropped in the last day. A civilian died nearly every hour. Each one of these figures is a reason why we should support a no-fly zone for Syria: www.whitehelmets.org

"Nobody who sees these images will ever be the same." That's what one ambassador said when these pictures smuggled out of Syria were shown at the United Nations.

Now a bunch of bureaucrats have banned the exhibition from the European Parliament in Brussels, saying they're "offensive and disturbing". It's ridiculous. These politicians shouldn't be protected from the reality of what's happening in Syria. If they don't know what's going on, what hope is there that they're going to try and stop it? 

Martin Schulz - the European Parliament President - can overturn their decision, but he's dragging his feet. 

Send him an email now: https://act.thesyriacampaign.org/letter/europe-stop-hiding-crimes?source=FBMartin

CALLING ALL TWITTER-ERS (ok, I know that's not what you call them).

We want to get the word out to EVERY Member of the European Parliament that hiding this Caesar exhibition from politicians is unacceptable. We've pulled together a little tool where you can tweet 579 of them directly. The instructions are in this document. If you don't tweet yourself, then please tag someone in the comments you might know who does.

These torture victims deserve more than silence from Europe's politicians.

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1N1-rHrVsN4sHjA1ytGdK1jbJdbz4DRgQVXg7FTF830k/edit#gid=287632719

It's scandalous. The European Parliament has refused to exhibit pictures showing torture under the Syrian regime calling them "disturbing and offensive".

Yes, these are deeply uncomfortable pictures. But the politicians who can stop it are precisely the kinds of people who *should* see these pictures. They've been shown at the United Nations, the Holocaust Museum in DC and the US Congress. There is absolutely no reason why European politicians should be allowed to turn away and ignore this reality.

In 48 hours more than 2500 of us have sent emails to the President of the European Parliament Martin Schulz to reverse this shameful decision. Lets keep the pressure on. Take action and share.
link_name: European Parliament: don't hide Syria's war crimes

Mohammed Kdad, a 22-year-old member of the White Helmets got married a few days ago. Instead of embarking on a honeymoon with his new bride, Mohammed resumed his work in the civil defense forces after the celebrations ended. Yesterday, as he was on his way to the town of Jisr al-Shughour in Idlib province with his team, he decided to pick up some groceries at the public market and drop them off at his house. His team members told him they would wait for him at the end of the road. But Mohammed never joined them as promised.

The second he set foot in the market, three thermobaric missiles launched by government forces landed. Thermobaric weapons produce a prolonged pressure pulse that is infinitely more lethal than standard explosives and the internal injuries they can cause are nearly impossible to treat.

Mohammed's team rushed back to the public market to start looking for survivors – a daily routine for them. Mohammed was gravely wounded, but he made it. He is in critical condition and is being treated at a hospital in Antakya. 60 Syrians, however, did not make it that day and 120 more were injured.

Donate to Mohammed and The White Helmets: www.whitehelmets.org

Have a watch of this video from our friends at the Breathless campaign (and like their page). Here's what they say:

"German companies supplied the Syrian regime with material and goods for the production of chemical agents - agents that are used against the people of Syria today. Like Iraq in the past, Syria was not capable of building chemical weapons without vital support from Europe.  German companies helped with knowledge, infrastructure and goods. This makes them accomplices to the crimes committed against us and our children.

This is a message to the people of Germany. Show that you don't want your companies to trade in chemicals of death. Support the people of Syria!"

(Powerful story from friends at Humans Of Syria الإنسان في سوريا, please like their page.)

Dr Majed lived and treated patients under the starvation siege of the Damascus suburbs. For years, images emerged quietly of emaciated adults and children succumbing to hunger in those neighbourhoods. But away from the world's spotlight and our news headlines, Dr Majed and his heroic team of medical workers were working frantically to save lives.

Dealing with hunger wasn't the half of it - Eastern Ghouta faced up to 70 air attacks a day. And with every attack comes a story. Listen to Dr Majed tell one of them in this incredibly touching video, then take action here: https://medicsunderfire.org/?source=drmvid

Isis has taken over the ancient Syrian city of Palmyra. Its people are currently hiding in their homes, scared of airstrikes by the Syrian regime from the sky, and attacks from Isis on the ground. Non-violent activists from the Planet Syria campaign are calling for global support for their demands to end the violence and stop extremism. 

Find out more and join their call: www.planetsyria.org

Stand with Syrians who are facing the dual threats of Bashar al-Assad's regime and Isis. 

Join The Syria Campaign: http://www.thesyriacampaign.org/?source=fbpalmyra

In September 2011, Fox News ran a poll on its website asking readers whether the United States should intervene in Syria. Assad's father-in-law emailed Assad and his clique a link to the poll urging them to ask their friends to vote "NO" to counter the flood of "YES" votes. Assad promptly forwarded the link to a close friend residing in France with the accompanying sinister message: 'again and again'.

Assad chooses to bomb his people into submission again and again, but in order to influence public opinion in the US he resorts to voting in a Fox News poll again and again...

Isis is in Palmyra. And there are now confirmed reports of multiple beheadings carried out by their fighters. 

Non-violent activists in Syria know there is only one way to stop Isis: stop the violence in Syria. That requires two steps that they cannot do alone: (1) an end to the Assad regime's barrel bombs and air strikes and (2) negotiations between all Syrian groups and their international backers. 

Read their call and join their campaign: www.planetsyria.org

In the latest bloody denouement in the Syrian war Palmyra has fallen to the extremist group ISIS, but just four years ago Syrians took to the streets and held peaceful demonstrations against the Syrian regime. They waved flags, locked arms and performed celebratory dances expressing their hope for change in forward-looking songs and leaflets.

Four years later, bleakness permeates news of ISIS advances across Syria. The same civilians who had demonstrated peacefully in Palmyra are now hiding in their basements as they await the next airstrike by the Syrian regime or the next beheading at the hands of ISIS fighters now roaming their streets.

We must not forget the peaceful beginnings of the Syrian people's uprising against injustice. The world stood by and watched as Syrians tried to overcome repression with humorous slogans, jubilant songs and all kinds of creative dissidence.

Regime forces crushed that peaceful movement compelling some Syrians to take up arms. The armed opposition soon splintered into militias headed by warring warlords. Civilians lost hope and the prolonged fighting led to a vacuum that ISIS rushed to fill.

Remember that every story has a beginning. If you want to prevent a bad ending to a story with a great beginning, stand with the people of Syria and end the bloodshed so that they may one day realize the dreams they sang about during their early demonstrations. Please take the time to watch this anti-regime demonstration that took place in Palmyra in 2011.

While the world is rightly outraged about the threat of Isis to the incredible ruins of Palmyra, let's not forget Palmyra prison, where thousands of Syrians have been tortured and killed by the regime of Bashar al-Assad.

Join The Syria Campaign and work to protect Syrian civilians whoever is killing them: www.thesyriacampaign.org/?source=fb05pm

From smiles to terror -- this is what war looks like. 

Photographer Bassam Khabieh tells the story of this picture. 

"Whenever the aid convoy entered the Eastern Ghouta, children would gather around it, happy that they were going to be supplied with food and medicine. While I was there, the children asked me to take their pictures so they could see them on the camera's screen. The children gathered around me so I could photograph them. First I took a photo of Ghazal, then her sister Judy who was carrying a baby called Suhair asked me to take a picture of her kissing the baby. While I was taking these photos, a shell landed on the area. The children started to scream and cry amid the dust and blood around them. The shell killed a female volunteer from the Red Crescent. The children were terrified, especially when they saw the female volunteer covered with blood. 

This was the first time I had seen how children's innocent laughter could turn into screams, fear and tears. Seconds before the strike, the children were looking at me happily, getting ready for a picture. It was a very sad moment when I put my eye to the viewfinder to take pictures of laughing children; then when I looked back after taking the picture, I saw the same children crying, distraught."

Barrel bombs are no fairytale. They've killed over 2,000 children in the past year alone.

I fled my house about two years ago, and I returned two months ago to find it like this.

I come to sit here every day and feel anguish at this situation we've reached. We don't ask much from God, just to end these sad days and have our house back, and our happiness."

"I was studying dentistry, but I stopped during my fourth year in 2012. There was a shortage of doctors in Eastern Ghouta, so I volunteered two and half years ago. 

Then all the roads were closed—the siege had begun.
In the beginning there were no centralized emergency points—just separated groups of medical aid teams who I volunteered with. Over time, a medical office was opened and I volunteered in the emergency department.

After several months, I started volunteering with the Syrian Arab Red Crescent (SARC) where we divided our work between medical and emergency work, vaccines, psychological support, and school health lessons for children.

The idea of psychological support for children is to try to make them feel happy through a variety of activities within our capabilities and ideas. We sometimes organize entertainment activities for the injured children who have a long road to recovery and get bored and upset. We organize small concerts when they feel up to it to try and make them feel better. I am delighted when I see a smile on their faces; that's when I feel I did my job well and I've made a great achievement.

I divide my time between SARC, the ER in the medical center and dental clinics in addition to some local development activities, like helping to organize courses in international law.

I live on my own in Eastern Ghouta. The first period was really hard. I learned how to cook and do the laundry and all the housekeeping myself. But after a while I got bored and moved to the medical center to live with the other young volunteers who are alone here too. And we became like a family. Everything I own is in my backpack, which I take with me almost everywhere."

Photo: Humans Of Syria الإنسان في سوريا

"We cannot look at Syria, and the evil that has arisen from the ashes of indecision, and think this is not the lowest point in the world's inability to protect and defend the innocent."

Truth.

In the past three weeks alone, 1,300 refugees have perished at sea making the journey from conflict and persecution.

"A Seagull In The Mediterranean" by Fares Cachoux.

Today as I drove down the streets of Glendale, cars and homes raised their Armenian flags high and proud. My eyes teared. During middle school & high school, many of my friends and classmates were Armenian, and of course I became very aware of the #ArmenianGenocide, and stood in solidarity with them. But in all honesty, it's not until today where I really understood how it felt. For the past four years of crisis in Syria, the media & international community continue to use words like "alleged chemical weapons attacks" ... "supposed massacre of children by government forces"... "to be inspected by international observers" ... "to be confirmed by independent experts". So the feeling is all too real to me now, when the crimes against humanity and their perpetrators are clear as day, and yet no justice served. And for that to be a reality for 100 years, where to date organizations, countries, and people continue to question or deny an atrocity...to put it simply, it is shameful.

Please put politics aside and join humanity.

"I'm for truth, no matter who tells it. I'm for justice, no matter who it is for or against. I'm a human being, first and foremost, and as such I'm for whoever and whatever benefits humanity as a whole." - Malcolm X.

By Nada Hashem.

Some are saying this poem was written by someone on a boat before they drowned in the Mediterranean, but we can't verify the author. Either way, this speaks the truth. Here's an English translation from the original Arabic.

----

I am sorry Mother that the ship sunk and that I couldn't get there and pay off the debts from the journey,

Don't be sad mother that they didn't find my body, for what use could it be to you now, except for the cost of transport, the funeral and burial,

I'm sorry mother that war came to us and I had to leave like the others, although my dreams were not big like theirs,

As you know, all my dreams were the size of a box of medicine for your colon, and the cost of fixing your teeth. On that note, my teeth are now green from the colour of the algae clinging to them,

Despite that, they are still more beautiful than the dictator's teeth,

I am sorry my dear for building you a house of illusions. A wooden cottage like the ones we saw in movies. A humble cottage far away from the barrel bombs, far away from sectarianism, ethnic loyalties and the rumours of our neighbours,

I am sorry brother that I couldn't send you the fifty Euros that I promised you at the beginning of every month so you could have a good time ahead of your graduation,

I am sorry sister that I didn't send you the new mobile phone that has wi-fi like the one your better-off friend has,

I am sorry my beautiful home that I will never hang my coat behind your door,

I am sorry dear divers and search and rescue workers, for I don't know the name of the sea I drowned in,

Rest easy immigration department, for I won't be a heavy burden on you,

Thank you dear sea for welcoming us without a visa or a passport. Thank you to the fish who will share me without asking about my religion or political beliefs,

Thank you to the news channels who will report the news of our deaths for five minutes every hour for two days,

And thank you for grieving us when you hear the news… I'm sorry I drowned.

----

Syrians are the largest group risking this "trip of death" on overcrowded boats to get to safety across the Mediterranean. Of course Europe should have a proper rescue service at sea. But if we really want to save Syrian lives, the most effective way is to make them safe in the homes they don't want to leave. That means stopping the barrel bombs, chemical weapons and violence they're fleeing from. Join the call from Syria's volunteer rescue workers for a no-fly zone to protect civilians www.whitehelmets.org?source=fbmed. It's a critical step towards peace.

"This is very personal

I look back now and remember the protests; the voices that screamed freedom while i gazed at tears stampeding through the faces of grown women and men.

I look back now and remember the armed men who ran towards us with orders to shoot but could not find the hate inside them to do so and threw down their weapons and joined our lines and chanted 'we are one'

I look back now and remember those that managed to hate us, and made martyrs of us, only we would carry our martyrs on our shoulders with pride, all of us now, standing in the very front row

I look back now and remember a mother who said to me, "it is our duty to sacrifice my son" i believed her words were genuine, for the blood on her hands and her son laid still on her lap were pure witness to this

I look back now and remember the solidarity of humans from around the world who stood by us and offered what they could and said, "we love you and support you" we are forever in debt to them.

I look back now and remember my friends, the only people i trusted all died because they believed, because they were beautiful human beings, far braver than I.

I look back now and remember my father as he stood on Syrian soil for the very first time in 30 years and screamed into the crowd in Binnish "we poets write with pens but you the people, you have written poetry with your blood"

I look back now and remember Bara al Bouhsi stripping his ranks of his shoulders and throwing his weapon to the ground swearing that he would never kill to gain justice only to die with his camera in his hand.

I look back now and remember the brother of a tortured revolutionary, he could not cope to imagine what his brother was going through, his brother died, as did he on a mission to relieve him of his pain.

I look back now and remember Syrians of all colors open their doors to freedom only to welcome murderers in, who would attempt destroy their lives.

I look back now and remember fleeing Syria and looking back at my country across the border with shame, I took picture that day to remind me of that feeling, that shame.

I look back and now and remember the look of my brothers face as he watches the pain of our people wreck their insanity, His words sink in me, his heart breaks my very essence. ارحمني يا ضياء

I look back now and remember who I was before all this, sure that thats still not what I want now, i could never give in to that, I love the people i met in this revolution.

I look back now and remind myself that even if there is no road forward there is no turning back, even if we must build our paths each individually and meet each other somewhere sooner or later, there is no turning back.

From now on if I am asked to rest I will say 'I look back now and remember; there is no reason to rest for there is no reason to forget'."

-- Rami Jarrah

status_message: So many lovely, creative messages from all over the world were sent to Planet Syria. Thanks for participating! Share this video below with friends and let's keep the momentum going!

"I live in a simple area. Life was beautiful and simple here before the blockade, but after the regime siege, life became really hard. There are no more cookies or chips or any of my favorite foods. There's not even flour at home, and when we manage to find some, we need to gather firewood so mom can make bread. 

What we need the most is money for food. Flour is hard to find because of the siege, and so is firewood because there's no fuel or gas. My father is injured, so he can't leave the house to get these things.

Despite the snow and the terrible cold, I came out of the house today. But I didn't get to go play like other kids in the world--I had to go look for food and firewood. But I didn't find anything anyway because of the snow. So why shouldn't we just play in the snow?"

-Mahmoud, 6 years old
(He has been living under siege for the past two years)
Douma, Syria

Photo: Humans Of Syria الإنسان في سوريا

"We don't know who created the barrel bomb – it is a deadly instrument. Was it Russia? Iran? The Syrian regime fills a barrel with TNT, metal scraps, stones and nails. It's almost 500 kilograms. There are three sizes actually 250, 300, and 500 kilograms.

We've now got the experience and can tell the size of each barrel based on the extent of the destruction. A barrel of 500 kilograms destroys an area including up to 10 civilian buildings full of civilians including women and children. The structure of our buildings is not so strong, it is not reinforced cement. It is block which crumbles."
-Khaled, White Helmet, Aleppo.

If you want a Syria without bombs like The White Helmets, sign here: https://www.whitehelmets.org/?source=fb14p

In the last five days the regime has dropped more than 43 barrel bombs and fired 12 interstitial missiles on Aleppo killing more than a hundred people. 

This video was filmed there this week and gives a window into both the terror and the heroic actions of the White Helmets. It's not gory. Just heartbreaking. 

These attacks will not be on your nightly news but they are why we need a no fly zone to protect civilians. Sign now: https://www.whitehelmets.org

"The suffering in Syria must end. 

We cannot go on forever listening for the sounds of survivors through the collapsed roofs of schools and clinics. We cannot go on carrying the bodies of children killed in a conflict they had no part in. 

Every bomb that drops deepens Syria's cycle of violence and extremism."

-Raed, Head of The White Helmets. Support his call for a no fly zone now. 

https://www.whitehelmets.org/?source=fb13p

"We are peaceful people, and we hate killing and war. When a fighter or bomb strikes, I worry about my daughter and relatives. I thank God that my wife believes what I believe: 'Never will we be struck except by what Allah has decreed for us'.

But children are a different story, as you cannot control their fear."
-Khaled, White Helmet

Only 3 DAYS until we send a signal to Planet Syria - كوكب سوريا. On Tuesday, April 7th let's tell thousands of nonviolent Syrian activists that we've heard them, that we stand with their efforts to make peace.

What are you doing? It doesn't have to be big, you can hold a sign up and take a picture if you don't have much time – but let's make sure Planet Syria hears from every corner of our world. Post your pictures and video to the Planet Syria Facebook page or send over email to info@planetsyria.org. Check out the ideas below and get involved:
- Write a message in the sand on a beach then stand next to it
- Make a big banner and take a picture outside somewhere iconic – City Hall, a famous monument
- Get the chalk out, write on the pavement
- If you belong to a faith group, gather this weekend and take a photo
- Graffiti (we won't tell if you don't)
- Play a song for Syria with your favourite musical instrument 
- Get the paints out and get your kids involved
- Group shot: gather your family, your office colleagues, your football team and take a picture. "Planet Syria we hear you!"
- Temporary tattoos: Care about it? Write it on your body. (If you're feeling daring, get a permanent one

"We are able to know the contents of the barrel bomb, because some fall, but don't explode. Inside the barrels they mix chemical fertiliser, TNT and metal materials like iron blades and pieces of metal porch posts. The contents are picked in order to ensure the maximum damage to people."
-Khaled F, The White Helmets

More than 2000 barrel bombs were dropped on civilians last year. 99% of them exploded killing thousands and injuring more.

Today Isis entered this besieged community and it became world news again. If we had done more to lift this siege the people of Yarmouk would have had the resilience to protect their community. We let Isis into Yarmouk.

Last night the Syrian regime dropped barrel bombs filled with chlorine gas onto civilians in Idlib. Six people were killed -- a grandmother, mother, father and three children. Dozens more were treated for gas inhalation at a nearby field hospital.

Today, the White Helmets are asking the United Nations Security Council to stop these chemical weapons being dropped - with a no-fly zone if necessary. The more of us who join the call, the greater the urgency on leaders to act.

The attack comes just 11 days after the UN Security Council voted on a resolution saying it would take further measures, including the possibility of military force, if chlorine gas was used again in Syria. Now it has been used. The Syrian regime is testing us -- if the international community doesn't take action, if our leaders break their word, it will be a green light for thousands more to be killed using poison gas.

The attack also comes 390 days after the UN Security Council passed a resolution banning the use of barrel bombs. Despite these threats the Syrian regime is doing nothing to ease its attacks on civilians. On Sunday it launched more than 200 air attacks.

Act now to stand with the White Helmets and their call for a no fly zone: https://www.whitehelmets.org/?source=fbln

This is Aleppo. The oldest continuously inhabited city in the world. Now the most dangerous city in the world. 

To keep residents safe from sniper fire, makeshift barricades of buses are raised. The world needs to see this. Share.

Hamza Al Khatib was 13 years old when he was detained by the regime at a protest in Daraa. His body was delivered to his family less than a month later, bearing marks of severe torture and mutilation. Hamza became a symbol of an uprising that was to ensure a dignified future free of oppression for Syria's children. This week marks four years since the beginning of the Syrian uprising - a peaceful protest movement calling for dignity and democracy.

Hamza Al Khatib (October 24, 1997 - May 25, 2011)

Four years ago when the uprising in Syria began, activists organised underground using incredible nonviolent tactics.

The Strike for Dignity was a nationwide strike organised by Syrians in December 2011. Across Syria shopkeepers and merchants closed their doors in a nonviolent expression of solidarity with the revolution and against the dictatorship of Bashar al-Assad. In many cases, Syrian security forces stormed markets, breaking locks and forcing shopkeepers to re-open for business. This iconic poster was used to promote the strike.

This week marks four years since democracy protests erupted in Syria. Ghiath Matar, "a tailor with a fondness for flowers", was a pro-democracy activist who became known for passing out roses and water bottles to regime forces who showed up to crush protests. He was nicknamed "Little Ghandi" for the peaceful protests he organised in his hometown of Daraya calling for freedom and democracy.

He was detained for his activism, his body returned four days later to his family bearing torture marks. Today we remember.

status_message:
Four years ago Syrians rose up peacefully demanding freedom. And there's no demonstration like a Syrian demonstration. In 2011, on Fridays, thousands, sometimes hundreds of thousand, would gather to call on the president to step down and chant their demands for freedom. Syrian flags spanning kilometres in length would be held up by hundreds of protesters. Entire families would come along. 

This is a video of a major demonstration in Assi Square, Hama on 1 July, 2011. Across Syria that day, hundreds of thousands protested under the banner of "Irhal" or "Step Down".
link_name: حماة - ساحة العاصي - مظاهرة في جمعة ارحل 1/7/2011

"This is is a photograph of a picture of where I am from.

This was our farm in Syria.

I used to go and feed the sheep most days. There we couldn't hear any cars.

There aren't so many people there and you know them all, you don't meet new people every day like you do in Beirut.

In those days we were living in the cave. We made it a year before we left Syria. We were hiding there from the bombing.

We made it very warm and cosy in there. Inside the temperature was always the opposite of outside — in summer it was cool and in winter it was warm.

We used to sleep in there. We couldn't feel the difference between day and night because there was no light, so once my mum slept from 6pm to 8pm the next day. It was raining, there was a storm."

- Ibo, 17

See more pictures from Ibo and others at Beirut Friends: Our Life in Photos, a blogging project with Syrian refugee and Lebanese kids in Beirut, which uses photography as a way for them to talk about their experiences and share their world with others. https://medium.com/beirut-kids-photo-diaries

¿Adivina qué está haciendo el ejército de EE.UU. con información decisiva para salvar un número incontable de vidas en Siria? Absolutamente nada. 

EE.UU tiene acceso a información de radar del espacio aéreo sirio. Ahora mismo, alguien está sentado en un centro de control militar estadounidense observando aviones del régimen rebosantes de bombas de barril dirigiéndose hacia escuelas, hospitales y hogares, aunque haciendo nada por advertir a los sirios de los bombardeos inminentes.

El Consejo de Seguridad de la ONU prohibió las bombas de barril hace exactamente un año. Desde entonces, los barriles bomba han asesinado casi 2.000 niños. Si la comunidad internacional no va a parar las bombas, al menos podría advertir a los equipos de rescate sirios, como los Cascos Blancos, de los bombardeos que se avecinan. Ésta es una información crucial que salvará vidas.
link_name: Gobierno de EE.UU.: advierta a las familias sirias sobre ataques inminentes con bombas de barril

احزر ماذا تفعل إدارة أوباما بالمعلومات الحساسة التي يمكن أن تنقذ عدداً لا يحصى من الناس في سوريا؟ لا شيء على الإطلاق.

بمستطاع الولايات المتحدة الآن الوصول إلى معلومات رادارية عن المجال الجوي السوري. فالآن, يجلس شخص ما في مركز تحكم للمؤسسة العسكرية للولايات المتحدة ويراقب طائرات النظام المحملة بالبراميل المتفجرة تتوجه نحو المدارس, والمشافي, والمنازل دون القيام بأي فعل لتحذير المدنيين السوريين من الهجمات الوشيكة.

لقد حظر مجلس الأمن استخدام البراميل المتفجرة منذ عام بالضبط. ومذ ذلك الحين قتلت البراميل المتفجرة 2,000 طفل. لم يقم المجتمع الدولي بإيقاف البراميل المتفجرة, فأقل ما يمكنه فعله تحذير عناصر الدفاع المدني السوري – كعناصر الخوذ البيضاء – من هجمات البراميل الوشيكة. إن هذه المعلومات ستنقذ الكثير من الأرواح.
link_name: الحكومة الأمريكية: حذروا العائلات السورية بخصوص هجمات البراميل المتفجرة القادمة

status_message:
"I used to work near here on an archeological site, helping with the digging and excavation, so I used to pass these steps every day.

When I was in Syria, at one point we had to dig out a cave, because our house was in a bad situation, and my mum wasn't feeling well. She needed a safe place where she could stay because she couldn't move, and once my dad was shot at. Many people came to the cave to take shelter so we needed a place that could offer protection to a lot of people.

So we made the cave. When we were doing that, I liked how you put the stones in place next to each other, and their colours.

What I liked about working on the archeological site here in Beirut was that it reminded me of that and made me see that every single stone is different — in Syria and here too.

We were unearthing Roman and Ottoman ruins here. The company is still excavating there but I stopped working because I wanted to study.

I am studying cooking and hospitality at the Mouvement Social centre. I hope I can find a job in this when I finish."

- Ibo, 17, from Homs countryside

A boy in Homs. With a message on his shirt that's being totally ignored. 

The Syrian Network for Human Rights reported that 6,163 civilians have been killed in barrel bomb attacks since last February.

"When my mum was pregnant with my youngest sister, we were still in Syria. She went for her final check up, and there was something wrong, and the doctor told her 'you have to give birth now'. But the hospitals weren't working because of the war, so my mum went to the house of a female doctor who had been delivering babies at home, and the baby was induced there.

But the doctor made a mistake and gave her more of the drug than her body could take. Her womb fell apart. They had to drive all the way to another town to get to a hospital. When they arrived she was almost dead, and the soldiers in front of the hospital had to give blood because she had lost so much.

My mum's heart stopped three times during the operation; three times the trainee doctors said 'she's dead, let's give up'. But the head doctor said 'No. We have to keep on' — and she survived.

So we really love our baby sister. She talks now and whenever she says anything people fall in love with her. She's a miracle baby, and it's a miracle that our mum made it back to life again.

The doctors were suggesting different names — 'Life', 'Survivor', but my mum had already decided on 'Peace'."

- Stephanie, 14.
