(Good news - a few days ago the UN Security Council finally banned the trade in Syrian antiquities. Here's a message from Dr Amr Al-Azm who led our campaign)

It's a huge victory for all of us who care about world heritage and want to prevent that priceless history being sold into weapons. We have known for a long time that the dramatic looting and destruction of historical sites in Syria has been a source of income for fighters on all sides.

Eight months ago, when we started this campaign together nobody was pushing for a UN ban on the trade in Syrian antiquities. So how did we get here?

- In July we launched a public petition calling for the UN ban -  22,432 people signed from more than 125 countries, promoted by people with millions of followers like Ian McKellen (or Gandalf, to some of us)

- In September we spoke to archaeologists and art historians around the world publishing an open letter with more than 80 prominent academics calling on the UN to introduce the ban. The story was featured in the New York Times, LA Times, Newsweek and others. Experts kept signing on - last week before the ban was introduced we passed 250 names.

- We were also invited to assist the sanctions monitoring team from the UN Security Council by providing valuable information on how looted antiquities were funding Isis and the Al Nusra Front group

- Then in December, we participated in a UNESCO conference along with high-level politicians and professionals focusing on the protection of cultural heritage in Syria and Iraq

And now, finally, in February of 2015 we have a UN ban.

An achievement of this scale is never down to an individual or group and there have been dozens of experts and diplomats from around the world who have been pushing to make this ban happen. There are too many to list but this would never have happened without their efforts. Huge thank you to them.

But the real heroes protecting the world's heritage in Syria are the archaeologists on the ground. Every day they are putting their lives in danger by protecting sites and convincing their communities not to turn to looting as the pressures of the conflict deepen. They do this so that people they will never meet in future generations can appreciate the deep cultural legacy of Syria's ancient history. Like the heritage these heroes are attempting to defend, they live and work on all sides in the Syrian conflict and represent a hope that one day we can heal the rifts in my country by reconnecting with the symbols that unite us.

It is my deepest hope that as we build this campaign from this significant achievement, we can do more to support those doing that critical frontline work.

Thank you for being a part of it,

Dr Amr al-Azm

Head of the Syrian Heritage Task Force
Associate Professor of Middle East History, Shawnee University
Professor at the University of Damascus (1998-2006)
Director of Science and Conservation Laboratories at the General Department of Antiquities and Museums in Syria (1999-2004)

"Being trapped under the rubble is something that I will never forget. I was on call that night with the emergency teams and then slept in the morning because it was Ramadan and we were fasting.

A barrel bomb fell in the Sad al-Wazz neighborhood, so the rest of my team rushed to the site. At one point they came back and woke me up suddenly. They told me there was a man stuck beneath the rubble. I got dressed immediately and accompanied them to area.

The man was trapped in a narrow place. I made a hole in the ceiling and crawled inside to where he was. I started clearing up the stones from around him. Just as I was almost done freeing his head and reassuring him that it was all almost over, I heard a terrible noise. I looked through the hole I had crept through, and I saw legs running. There was another explosion and I saw light and flames and the walls and ceilings started to fall on top of me.

My clothes were shredded due to the force of the explosion. My abdomen became swollen, but then went back to its usual size. My entire body felt funny. I fainted and then when I woke up I started shouting and yelling but it was all in vain. I checked my body for injuries and luckily everything was fine so I started moving the stones and dirt from around me and tearing things apart with my fingers. I was terrified that I was going to be stuck there forever. I kept working for half an hour and only then did I find a small gap for breathing – I felt like I was reborn.

Even though the air I breathed was full of gunpowder, it was the cleanest I'd inhaled in hours. I fell unconscious again and when I woke up, I was safe in the hospital. Thank god for everything. The only thing that was on my mind was my daughter. Only my daughter."
-Ibrahim, The White Helmets

status_message:
On Saturday, four White Helmet volunteers lost their lives trying to save others.

At 4 PM, Yasser Hindi, Omar Haj Ali, Ahmad Burghul and Hamza al-Mostafa finished their shifts and were heading home when they received a call about a car bombing at a checkpoint near the town of Masakan, just outside Aleppo. They were close to the site and rushed to help. They'd already begun aiding injured civilians when another car exploded, taking their lives and that of 15 others.

Another team arrived at the scene after the second explosion to help with rescue operations. Hamza's father, also a White Helmet, was with them. He discovered then that his son was among the victims.

Please leave your messages of condolences for the families and friends of Yasser, Omar, Ahmad and Hamza below.

This is a hard post to write. 

Yesterday rich countries met and agreed to resettle only 38,000 new refugees of the 3.3 million who have fled for their lives. This is the world's shame.

Over the last few weeks people like you have come together to send 10,000's of emails to European leaders, and with other organisations we've pushed the scandal of resettlement pledges from the back rooms of the UN to the front page of the news. But even that wasn't enough for yesterday -- national interests were too entrenched, politicians too scared of the right wing press and the compassion we needed them to demonstrate was almost entirely missing.

In the middle of pushing this campaign on resettlement another story hit the headlines: the World Food Programme suspended food vouchers to 1.7 million refugees due to a lack of funding from governments. 

WFP said part of the reason for suspending the food vouchers was because of "unfulfilled promises" from governments so we started to dig into the official UN figures - and we found a big, unexplained hole? With only 21 days left in 2014, the European Commission has failed to pay $48 million dollars it promised.  

So let's call on the European Commission to pay the missing $48 million immediately. This money has been promised to some of the world's most vulnerable.

ACT: https://thesyriacampaign.org/en/actions/promises-to-refugees

A year ago today, human rights defenders Razan Zaitouneh, Samira al-Khalil, Wael Hamada and Nazem Hammadi were abducted at gunpoint from their office in Douma near Damascus. Nothing has been heard of them since. Syria needs these heroes back - free the #Douma4

في محافظة إدلب المجاورة، متطوعوا الخوذ البيضاء ينقذون المدنيين من هجمات النظام وقصف التحالف. ولكي يزيد الطين بلة، زادت غارات النظام على بعض المناطق بشكل ملحوظ بعد بداية الغارات الجوية التي قادتها أميركا.
اليوم، الوضع الذي يواجه الخوذ البيضاء أسوء من ذي قبل. المتطوعون يحتاجون كل المساعدة التي يستطيعون الحصول عليها. معاً، بإمكاننا التأكد من حصولهم على جميع المعدات التي يحتاجون إليها لإنقاذ الأرواح. رجاء ساهموا بقدر ما تستطيعون الآن لشراء سيارات إسعاف للخوذ البيضاء. كل دولار يتبرع به سيذهب لشراء هذه السيارات.

"My name is Fatima and I am a mother of two young boys and a girl in one of the most dangerous places in the world. I am a volunteer for the White Helmets in Idlib. I help save people from destruction and attacks.

I am writing to you today to ask for your help to get three ambulances for our women's team here and three ambulances for the Aleppo team. Thank you for your support."

"Being trapped under the rubble is something that I will never forget. I was on call that night with the emergency teams and then slept in the morning because it was Ramadan and we were fasting.

A barrel bomb fell in the Sad al-Wazz neighborhood, so the rest of my team rushed to the site. At one point they came back and woke me up suddenly. They told me there was a man stuck beneath the rubble. I got dressed immediately and accompanied them to area.

The man was trapped in a narrow place. I made a hole in the ceiling and crawled inside to where he was. I started clearing up the stones from around him. Just as I was almost done freeing his head and reassuring him that it was all almost over, I heard a terrible noise. I looked through the hole I had crept through, and I saw legs running. There was another explosion and I saw light and flames and the walls and ceilings started to fall on top of me.

My clothes were shredded due to the force of the explosion. My abdomen became swollen, but then went back to its usual size. My entire body felt funny. I fainted and then when I woke up I started shouting and yelling but it was all in vain. I checked my body for injuries and luckily everything was fine so I started moving the stones and dirt from around me and tearing things apart with my fingers. I was terrified that I was going to be stuck there forever. I kept working for half an hour and only then did I find a small gap for breathing – I felt like I was reborn. 

Even though the air I breathed was full of gunpowder, it was the cleanest I'd inhaled in hours. I fell unconscious again and when I woke up, I was safe in the hospital. Thank god for everything. The only thing that was on my mind was my daughter. Only my daughter."
-Ibrahim, The White Helmets

Today marks the 60th birthday of Father Paolo Dall'`Oglio who was kidnapped in Raqqa, Syria and has been missing since July 2013.
His family has a birthday message for him: 

"Dear Paolo,
On 17 November, our present for you will be a prayer or a shared thought, even at a distance, on your 60th birthday. We propose it to those who love you in every corner of the world, at 7 pm Italian time.

We will pray for you and all the other persons deprived of their freedom. We will pray for the bishops and the priests from whom, like you, we had no news for a long time. We will pray for peace and justice in that region. We will pray so that a beacon of light or a soft breeze may bring comfort and support to you and to all the people that have been suffering for far too long.

Dear Paolo, we love you and we continue to wait for you with hope and persistence.
-Your family"

"I have been here with my siblings and my parents for three months now. We were bombed in Syria and our village was destroyed, so we fled. We only took our sleeping stuff.

I do not attend school. Instead, I sell handkerchiefs everyday until 8 pm. Here I am not afraid, but in Syria I was afraid of the bombs, tanks and fighter jets. 

I would like to go back to my village and school. I would like that all stick together and we get rid of Bashar al-Assad."
-Achmed, 14

status_message: Saving lives in Syria doesn't get any more direct than this. Aleppo and Idlib are two of the most dangerous places in the world right now.  The women of the White Helmets who work there need 6 ambulances to transport injured victims from bombing sites to safety.  Have a dollar to spare? Contribute what you can and share this with your friends: http://bit.ly/1zmPrHM

56 brave Syrian women have banded together to save lives. And now they're calling on people from around the world to help them save lives. They need 6 ambulances, each costing $15,000. Chip in what you can and let's get them much-needed equipment! http://bit.ly/1zmPrHM

Here's a message from one of the new recruits:

"My name is Fatima and I am a mother of three young girls in one of the most dangerous cities in the world. I am a volunteer for the White Helmets in Idlib. I help save people from destruction, from the daily barrel bombs and other attacks on Syrian civilians.

I have a dream of building my country side by side with men. I drive an ambulance and help injured civilians every day, knowing that this will give my daughter and my country a better future.
I am writing to you today to ask for your help to get an ambulance for our women's team here and an ambulance for the Idlib team. We are now 56 women in Syrian Civil Defence, and having this victory will help us grow and grow.

Thank you for your support."

The 56 most inspiring women in the world. 

The women of the White Helmets are trained, kitted up and ready to save lives. But they need six ambulances, each costing $15,000. If we all chip in what we can afford, together we can buy these ambulances - it's the most direct way you can save lives in Syria today.

Until last month, almost all official members of the White Helmets were men. But now, two women's teams have been established -- and many more volunteers want to join them. Together, we can give them the giant boost they need by equipping two teams from Idlib and Aleppo with ambulances to respond to barrel bomb and missile attacks. 

Every day, these women rush to these scenes of destruction. With light tools and their bare hands, they dig survivors out from under the rubble. They give them medical care, and transport them to safety. And they risk their lives to do this. Often a helicopter or a jet will be circling overhead to launch another strike when rescuers and neighbours have gathered at the scene. 

Chip in what you can -- each donation will help these brave women save lives in Syria. And if you can't donate - please share!

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/support-the-women-saving-syria-from-the-bombs
link_name: Support the women saving Syria from the bombs

"My father is dead and I have been in Turkey with my six brothers and sisters and my mother for the last four months now.

I definitely want to return to Syria. But living here is also useful for me because I'm learning a new language. I have neither a cell phone nor Facebook, I am only learning for school.

My dream is to soon return to Syria with my mother and my brothers and sisters. We are waiting for the Arab world to help us, but where are they? Every day we wait for their help. We are Arab brothers, but nobody helps and I can not see any brotherhood."

"Yesterday, a bunch of us met at the crack of dawn outside the German foreign office, shivering in the cold, but happy to express our opinion on such an important day.

EU ministers were meeting in Berlin to talk about the situation of Syrian refugees living in Syria's neighbouring states. What they didn't do was talk about the fact that the EU itself has only agreed to take 1% of all of Syria's refugees, even though it's economy is so much bigger and wealthier. 

We took their meeting as an opportunity to make them understand how ridiculous their pledge is  - with a little satirical display of EU's refugee champions!"
-Emilie

السوريين هو خيانة لتاريخكم

بإمكان أوروبا القيام بأفضل من ذلك. يشهد العالم اليوم أكبر موجة من اللاجئين في أكبر أزمة لاجئين في العالم. في 28 تشرين الأول، سيجتمع وزراء خارجية من أغلب مناطق أوروبا في ألمانيا لمناقشة ما ينبغي القيام به. أضف اسمك لننادي أغنى دول أوروبا لإعادة توطين المزيد من اللاجئيين السوريين. سنكون في الميدان في برلين لنوصل هذه الرسالة بطريقة خلاقة إلى هؤلاء السياسيين وإلى الإعلام- كل ما زاد لدينا عدد الأسماء، كلما كنا أقوى.

"It was one Friday morning, a while before prayer time. We heard the sound, it was very close, we rushed there and when we arrived we found out that a barrel bomb was dropped on a vegetable market in Al Shaar area. There was huge destruction and there were some fuel shops in the area which caught fire.

We had to bring people down the balconies with the help of the fire fighting teams, because the stairs were destroyed.

This man was inside one of the burning shops. He was conscious but he had lost both legs - they were cut by a fragment of the barrel.

He wasn't able to see anything which scared him so much as you can probably can imagine what the last thing he'd seen was.

He needed to feel someone was with him all the time, so he held tight to that man's hand and wouldn't let go. In this picture we were looking at the destruction trying to find a safe way through to the ambulance.

18 people died that day and 30 were injured. Just another day in Aleppo."

-Alaa, The White Helmets

End the bombing of innocent people and their homes.

"I fled with my parents, my sister and my three brothers from Aleppo one year and seven months ago. Helped by smugglers, we crossed the border. The war in Syria is terrible and the general public is much more affected than the Syrian government.

I already went to school in Syria. Now I attend the Free Syrian School here. After school I go home and do my homework, make phone calls or surf the web.

I am talking a lot with my friends about the good times that we had in Syria and we are wondering why we have to live like this today.
I am happy when I think of the time before the war and my days in school then and that I again have the chance here to go to school.
I hope the war ends soon, and I'm afraid that the revolution has been all in vain.

At night, I have nightmares about the war in Syria. I have not taken anything from home and I just want to go back, nothing else. In the future I would like to work as a lawyer.

I hope that the war ends, so I can meet my relatives again and that the Syrian government disappears."

-Hadil, 14

"This photo was taken by Milad, our media guy. I found Blondie and brought her to the centre, she was as scared and confused as people are in Aleppo. I took care of her, cleaned and nurtured her. She's always around in the centre.

I like playing with cats, they're amazing. Whenever I am sad I just play with her, she's my friend and she never fails to make me feel better.

Cats in Aleppo have been through a lot. They don't understand what's going on. They don't understand why we people fight. And to be honest, I don't either."

-Abdullatif, one of the White Helmets.

"When we arrived at the bombing site there were tens of casualties, four burning shops, twelve burning bodies.

It was crazy out there, we don't have any oxygen masks that you need when rushing into a fire, but we had to act - people were burning.

It was REAL HELL.

But we went in anyway. We had to use our hands to put out the fire on some of the bodies.

We felt nothing. No fear. Not even the heat of the fire.

20 minutes later two of our team collapsed and we had to provide emergency medical care for them.

We knew it was wrong to go into those buildings without oxygen masks, but humanity won over logic. Just for the hope of saving even one life.

I think this is what happens to all the good guys."

Ibrahim Al Mawla, White Helmets - Aleppo.

"A message to the world...
In addition to the daily killing of civilians, the Syrian regime has bombed and killed today the people who had been helping, and would have helped many more innocent people... It killed an ambulance driver and a first aid worker and destroyed their vehicle which had served the people. They were martyred today while they were on their way to save civilians near Al-Haidariyya Roundabout.

Right after the bomb was dropped, a man and two children were martyred and 7 others were injured. Minutes later, the number rose to 11 and 19, respectively. Among those who were martyred was Wael, the first aid worker.

We dug a grave and buried Wael next to his fiance (a first aid worker), whom he himself had buried 19 days earlier. She had also been martyred by a barrel bomb in the Tarik Al-Bab area.

Abu Rayyan's life has come to end now, yet it has only increased our determination to go on and to continue saving the innocent people... Our message as the Civil Defence is: We vow to go ahead until the very end..." 

- Alaa, one of the White Helmets.

"This morning at around 09:00 in the old city of Aleppo, a barrel bomb was dropped on the street, very close to this family's house.

We arrived there very quickly and were told that in this house there was a man, 2 women and 6 children.

We started working, trying to get them out and luckily the barrel bomb that fell, dropped a few meters away so they all survived! Their lives actually were saved because of those few meters!

It was one of the few good days! At least for this family! As in the rest of the city 19 barrel bombs were dropped..."

-Ibrahim, The White Helmets

"One and a half years ago, my parents, my two brothers and I fled from Aleppo to escape the Syrian intelligence service. My father was wanted by the government and he was in great danger, but we escaped just in time, otherwise my father would have been arrested or killed.

My subjects at school here are math, history, chemistry, geography, physics and English. In my spare time I surf the Internet and play with my brothers or friends. I'm happy when I play with my friends and when I have the feeling that I am safe with my parents in Turkey. I am afraid that my father will be arrested if he returns to Syria.

Everything was stolen from our house in Syria, I did only take my laptop with me. I want to be good in school and hope that the war in Syria ends. In the future I would love to work as a doctor like my father.

I did not do anything on my birthday, but it was also the day when school started and I was very happy about this. And my father gave me a cake.

Everyone in the world should at least care a little about Syria, because it is terrible and many people have already died."

Nabil, 14

"We were having a kick about with a football since there was no bombing that day. Or at least so we hoped.

Suddenly, the regime's air force started bombing Hanano [a part of Aleppo] neighbourhoods, very close to us. So we rushed there like we always do and there was a big fire and it was spreading.

We called the firefighting team and we started pulling people out straight away. The guy I'm carrying here was one of them. Right after this picture was taken I dropped him off at the ambulance and went back for the others. It was a long day, but we did our best.

My friends in our rescue team call me "Ahmad the Tall" because of my height. I'm tall for a reason - so I can be better at carrying people!"
-Ahmad, #WhiteHelmets

"I felt air escaping and then the heat. Then quickly the billowing smoke spread over our car window. We were close to a blast. My fixer told me to get out quickly - a second barrel bomb would be coming.

It was close to the time people break their daily Ramadan fast in the crowded market. People haggled over prices of watermelons and food to take home to their families. It wasn't the time to be worrying, it was meant to be a time to celebrate - but within a moment all this changed. The government indiscriminately dropped a bomb on a populated area in the liberated part of Aleppo.

It was a massacre. Over tens of bodies had been found dead, many wounded. The smoke was clearing and the ambulances were on their way. We heard the second bomb go off in the distance and it gave us the message that we could work.

Over a hundred people scrambled carrying bodies, some wounded but most were dead. Those moving the debris were cursing the Syrian government and calling out in Allah's name for the misery to end.

I quickly photographed and then headed to the next site of the second barrel bomb. It was by a building in a quiet street. It was ripped apart at the foundations and it had the windows of what seemed to be a sports complex. Young men in karate uniforms stained with blood emerged, their faces confused and shocked trying to make sense of what had just happened.

Men with white helmets moved swiftly into the building helping to bring out the wounded. The building seemed on the verge of collapse but the men moved swiftly, organised.

The White Helmets as they are known work 24/7, everyday saving lives. Most have never had proper medical training, only the willingness to organise and head into danger in an effort to save lives. As the building began to buckle, part of a wall crumbled covering them in dust but they kept on searching until everyone could be accounted for.

As quickly as they had arrived, the White Helmets rushed to take the wounded to underground hospitals to help get them urgent treatment."

Jacob Simkin, Photojournalist
http://bit.ly/1nGgsip

status_message:
"After a bombing in Al Shaar we had an all night rescue operation. We saved one child from a family but the other two were missing. 

From 9:30pm to 2am we worked. We were exhausted, so a second team relieved us until 7am. When we arrived ready to take over again, we were targeted by the regime air force who fired a rocket that hit the next street, so we rushed there immediately - lots of people were gathered around but thank god there were no casualties, but two people were injured. 

We were afraid the regime would fire another rocket, as they always come back to the area of attack when people come to rescue to bomb them, so we started evacuating people in a hurry so no more lives would be lost. This picture was taken then! That boy holding my neck like that was one of the moments in which I knew why I am a civil defender!" 

Ahmed, White Helmet
Support him and his heroic efforts here: http://bit.ly/1reMS4v

Show your support of The White Helmets by adding this to your profile!  Together, we can make these selfless heroes famous.

Growing good from bad. 
A garden patch locals in Aleppo planted where a barrel bomb hit a sewage pipe.

September 3, 2014
Credit: AFP Photo / Zein Al-Rifai

Here, there are no employed firefighters or paramedics. Here, it can feel seemingly hopeless; where every citizen becomes a target of indiscriminate barrel bombs, and survival and rescue are completely uncertain...

Until The White Helmets come in. Fulfilling a duty. The duty to preserve humanity in the world's most dangerous place. Find out more here:
http://bit.ly/1qr31Ym

It's Wednesday. The middle of the work week. But when you're in the business of saving lives in the most dangerous place on earth, you're on call every day. 

Wanna learn more about this intense work and the heroes behind it?
http://bit.ly/1un4Sha

"We've been under a lot of pressure recently so my team advised me to take a few days off, and to come back fresh and energised. So I went on Friday to visit my uncle's house where I spent time playing with my little cousin Abdo.

My uncle insisted that I spend the night with them, but I wanted to go and rest so I went home.

The next day, someone from the Hanano rescue team [another part of Aleppo] called me to say that they need me there. I thought they must be facing a major crisis to want another team's support. But the reason they were calling me was because a barrel bomb hit my uncle's house and there were people under the rubble calling my name to rescue them.

I was depressed and confused and felt unable to do anything. I rushed there but when I arrived the situation was already very bad. Abdo, the little boy who was playing with me last night was gone. I collected the pieces of him I could find and put them in this blanket.

My other two cousins were under the rubble. We could hear them at first, but because we don't have bulldozers to lift the heavy rubble we couldn't save them.

This is just my story from one day - all of the guys in our teams have days like this. But part of our work is picking ourselves up and getting back out there. There are lives to save, and the bombs don't stop. I know it's what Abdo would want me to do."

- Ibrahim, one of the White Helmets. Here in the red t-shirt holding Abdo.

Please share Ibrahim's story with the world. Stand with the unarmed and impartial rescue volunteers of the White Helmets here: http://bit.ly/1rkr0Zn

The volunteers of White Helmets are humanity's heroes saving lives on the front line in Syria. Unarmed and neutral they scramble to bomb sites to dig survivors out the rubble.

The Syrian government has been dropping 'barrel bombs' on civilian areas despite a UN order to stop, targeting schools and hospitals. Those too poor to flee their homes can only hope that if the bomb drops, the White Helmets will be there to help get them out.

More than 30 volunteers have been killed in the the past few months alone.

They lack the basic kit they need to save more lives - shovels, helmets, air-raid sirens. We can pressure donor governments to release critical funding for these heroes.

Let's tell the world about the White Helmets and help get them the support they need: http://whitehelmets.org/

You've heard about James Foley and ISIS. You've heard about chemical weapons. You've heard about torture. You've heard about people being persecuted for their religious beliefs. In short, you've heard a lot about the bad guys.

Well now it's time to hear about the good guys. Syria has heroes.

The 'White Helmets', the volunteers of the Syrian Civil Defence save lives in the most dangerous place on earth. They don't kill, they don't even carry weapons. Instead they take a pledge of 'Humanity, Solidarity and Impartiality' in line with the international Civil Defence code to save lives wherever they can.

When the bombs rain down, the White Helmets rush in, looking for survivors amongst the rubble. Volunteer medics, firefighters and search & rescue workers many have paid the ultimate price to protect life - more than 30 have been killed in the past few months alone.

It's a symptom of modern reporting that you only hear about the bad guys. But Syria has heroes and they need the world's support.

The White Helmets are desperate for life-saving kit, from helmets to digging tools and air-raid sirens. There is money - governments around the world have pledged millions to support Syria but yet these brave men and women often lack the basics.

Please share their stories with the world. You can make these heroes famous and get them the life-saving support they need.

Sign the petition to get donor governments around the world to get the White Helmets the life-saving equipment they need today: https://www.whitehelmets.org/?viewedvideo=true

A year ago today, the Syrian government used Sarin gas against its own people killing over a thousand, many of them children. The world was outraged and demanded Assad destroy his stockpile of chemical weapons. Today chlorine gas is still being used on civilian neighbourhoods, rolled out the back of helicopters in rusty 'barrel bombs'.

The media may have turned away from what's unfolding daily in Syria but today we all have the tools to tell the world the truth. Please share widely and remember the children of Syria in your thoughts today.

BREAKING: Guardian releases Australian government emails detailing the lengths they are taking to try and return vulnerable Syrians back to a war zone.

"Australia is doing the unthinkable" - Human Rights Watch.

SIGN: http://bit.ly/VBCoDl

There are five Syrians currently on Manus island in Papua New Guinea where Australia has sent these asylum seekers. The centre is essentially a prison. The Syria Campaign spoke last week to three Lebanese citizens who had been detained with the five Syrians and spoke of the horrific conditions in which they are being held. The authorities have even separated these Syrians from each other to try and keep them quiet.

We are used to seeing the horror of Syria and Iraq on our TV screens and newspapers but what Australia is doing right now to the world's most vulnerable is no better. The Syrians have been hunger striking and one of them is even in a wheelchair he is so weak.

YOU CAN SPEAK OUT FOR THEM. Please share this story far and wide and sign the petition to the Australian government to stop imprisoning these Syrians and stop trying to send them back to a war zone.

PETITION: http://bit.ly/VBCoDl

Guardian story and the released emails: http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/19/australia-going-to-unthinkable-lengths-to-return-syria-detainees-emails-show

"They tied my hands behind my back, sat me on the ground and asked me how I was. No one said anything. They just used electricity for 40-50 minutes. I couldn't see or hear anything for 10 minutes. My system was completely confused. I couldn't stand up."

A message of encouragement and love. From one refugee to another.

To: Children of Syria in Jordan Refugee Camp

How are you my dear brothers and sisters? How is your situation over there? I hope you are fine. I am greeting you and I am alright and trying my best to settle down in my studies.

My brothers and sisters, I know that in your country there is war but no matter, work hard in your life.
So, I am encouraging you to learn and be educated in your country and go on with your learning. Without education, it is like you are in a dark place. So don't be hopeless, we are with you and if there is war in your country tolerance is necessary.

My friends I am telling you education is the key to success in your life, so be confident and be patient. I am advising you to go back to your country and build back your nation so that it may be good and well and the more you get tolerant the more you get goodness. So, be powerful to your country and be polite.

Are you working hard at your schools? Remember education is important in this world and over. So school is fine. It's only through education that you can live a better life.
I am wishing success in your life. May Allah bring back peace and stability in your country. I say goodbye my young brother and sister and have less worry and nice time. God bless you all.

Your loving sister,
Zahra Dahir Ali
Somalian refugee
